Phillipston Worcestor Co. Mass 
Jan 29 49
Dear brother
You not having fulfiled your prommice to write to me, I 
thought to remind you of it and to find out what business 
you thought best for me to go into this year. Mr George Kendall 
of the Westminster a cabinet maker mentioned to 
uncle Fry that he should like to take me till I was 
18 or 21 and learn me the trade and he being a likely 
and steady man a firstrate workman I should like 
to go and see how I liked him stay about a month or so 
and if I liked have the bargain put in writings. John 
worked for him last year and is a going to this he likes 
and would be company he says that they are good folks 
and he is Deacon of the orthodox church he has no farm but 
keeps 2 cows and 2 horses wants a boy to take care of them 
and learn the trade and go to school in the winters not 
knowing another place I thought I would send out 
word and see what you thought about it. mother is well 
and so are the rest of the folks our school has three weeks to 
keep not having time to write more I must bring 
this to a close as I have but a short time to turn my 
self in I wish you to write as soon as you recieve this 
so good by. 
Jesse Kendall.

Monday noon Jan 29th, 1849
Dear Brother
As Jesse was going to send a few 
lines to you thought I would just send a card 
How are you getting along now suppose well 
Mr. S. Howe of Petersham is dead. John Howe is 
quite poor so that he think of going to split palm- 
leaf for a living. Joseph Mory and Sophia Brown 
were over to see me last week they inquired very 
particularly for you Sophia said Jesse looked so 
much like you she wanted to kiss him.
There is to be a Dramatic exhibition at Petersham 
this eve want to attend very much.  Edwin has 
been having considerable trouble in school of late 
don't know how he is getting along now but hope 
well. Do you not think of going to California in 
search of gold that seems to be the talk this way 
Mr Benjamin Howe of Petersham and Charles Jenkins 
of Barre are going the 1st of March Please write soon 
Give my love to sis and take a share yourself 
You must excuse all amiss for I am at the 
school house in all the noise and my pen is 
very coarse &c. Jesse Kendall from the Cape is up now
Affectionately yours Lydia

Jan 3
Mr Nathan Kendall
Mt Washington,
Ky.
(Via Boston & Louisville)

Athol April 29th 1849 
Dear brother I recieved your letter 
last Febuary telling to write as soon 
as I had got matters arranged but sister 
Lydia haveing wrote you I thought to 
wait till I had found out how I liked at 
Mr. gobFrys  and haveing lived here about a month 
I thought that I could tell so thinking that 
I should like to hear from you and sis I 
thought to write I was at home last evening 
and the folks are well Erasmus has gone to 
Albany and Edwin to Vermont Erasmus 
sold his farm for 19 hundred dollars as probably
you know Isabellen Miller died yestaday morning 
and they have heard from William he was 
at Savannah sick with the fever and ague 
he could not stay their and was a going 
to North Carolina not haveing time to write

more I shall have to bring this to a close give my 
love to sis after reserved a part for your self 
write soon

from your ever loving brother Jesse

Mr. Nathan Kendall
Mt. Washington
Ky
(via Boston and Louisville)

[from Jesse]  

                      Marietta O  Nov 16th 1851
 Dear Brother
     I received your letter this morning

and though not in a mood to write I will
send you a few lines merely to let you
know how I am getting along am now at
work on the St. Bt. same Franklins' Capt
Geo Benedict running from here to Cincinnati
and expect to remain during the winter should
have gone to school this winter if I had any
clothes but he offered me the berth and
I excepted it have been on but just two
weeks had just got finely started in my
studies and was improving rapidly am
enjoying myself finely with plenty to
do for this is a hard trade Capt is a fine man
and I like him well. they are calling me and 
must close this hasty scratch.   Yours Kendall

[Jesse]
Mr. N. Kendall
Petersham
Mass
Worcester Co

[Jesse]
St. Louis Aug 31st/53
Dear bro Nathan
I received your kind letter 
last Saturday & have to plead indisposition 
for not answering it before because you
see I have got that western pet called the 
fever & ague & I assure you it is most romant-
incly delightful I have had bad luck the 
past spring & summer & if I had not have 
done pretty well last winter I do not know 
what I should have done for I have not more 
than one-half paid my way during the 
spring & summer So that it has eaten into

my winter wages till I had not $20 left 
but I think that I have a Doctor now that 
not only has broken the ague but will 
eventually cure me But such is the con-
dition of my shoulder that I am un-
fitted for hard work. You ask me if I 
have laid up anything . I have not but should 
of had over one hundred dollars clear if I 
had of had my health. You also wish to 
know how I would like Civil Engineer-
ing? I answer well, it would be my de-
light & something I have always wished 
to be I never have studied Geometry &
Algebra but slightly so that you see that 
I have some studying to do before I can 
take it up. What would be the studies 
for me to take up for to prepare my-
self for it. As I am not able to go to school 
at the present time do you not 
think that it would be better for me 
to get in as rodsman till I get 
the necessary ammount to got to 
school with for then I would be

getting an insight into the business 
what kind of a chance is there on the road that 
you are on in that respond? Do you stop in the 
office or go out upon the road? Is the road 
under progression yet or not? I am anxious 
to get to doing something that I can stand 
and will be of some improvement to me 
& if you go out upon the road & have as sec-
tion you of course will want a rods-
man & then why will it not be a chance 
for me but any way write me and l
et me know what you think is best 
& I will abide by your decision Your plan 
suits both sister & husband as well as 
myself. Remember me to Mr. Gleason 
that is if he remembers me
I remain your aff brother J. Kendall

[Jesse]
Saint Louis Sept 22nd/53
Dear bro. Nathan:
Your kind letter of 
the 14th inst has just reached me and ac-
cording to your kind request I now
will start another upon the way 
It rather throwed my calculations to 
the wind as far as employing myself 
this winter for today I was going 
out about ten miles from here to 
see about a school that they wish 
me to teach this winter as near 
as I can find out it is a school

pleasantly situation and a fine 
intelligent class of people around 
it and they pay very good wages 
I thought from all I could hear of the 
place it was such a school that 
I should like and one in which I could 
enjoy myself during the win-
ter & not knowing what to do about 
it or how soon I should have 
a call from you I have concluded 
to go out and see about the school 
& if I can get it try and make a-
rrangements so if I have to leave it 
will be satisfactory to the trus-
tees Friday noon. Well brother I 
have just returned from the school 
& have engaged to teach three 
month commencing next Wed-
nesday at twenty-five dollars 
per month and boarded & to 
teach twenty days for a 
month. They wished me to 
teach ten months but I 
would not engage for

that length of time still they 
said that if I was liked and 
would stay they would 
keep me ten months longer 
or even a year It is a pleasant 
schoolhouse painted white fin-
ished off inside like the school
houses in the East & as far 
as I have seen of the people 
they all appear like sensible 
people so that I anticipate 
a pleasant time but whether 
it will be so or not time alone 
will tell you will see from 
this what my prospects are 
so that you will know what 
to do for me upon the road 
In this matter I have gone ac-
cording to sister & brother W. ad-
vice sister says that she thought 
that I had better take the school 
although she is anxious to have 
me with you as soon as every-
thing is arranged satisfactory

The folks all wish to be kindly 
remembered to you and trusting 
that this will find you enjoy-
ing good health
I remain your aff. bro.
JK Kendall
Please ask Mr Gleason if he re-
members that little boy that 
came West with him tell 
him that he is man enough 
now to raise a pair of whiskers 
JKJr

[Jesse]
Jackson's Collegiate Institute
Patriot May 10 1854
Dear Bros. N. and D. and Sister J. 
You will 
see by the above that I am a "school-boy" now at 
this place; and I isantily sick of it to am I, and 
had I known as much about this place as I do now 
I should never have come; but as it is I must make 
the best of it and take warning in future and 
not trust to much to advertisements. For without 
any exceptions whatever and to tell nothing but the plain, 
honest, and candid truth, this school is one of the greatest 
humbugs that is now in existence and makes any preten-
tions of being a school. By the looks of the advertise-
ments one might suppose that there would be at least 
twenty-five students here any way if not one hundred 
and twenty-five; but instead of that there are only 
seven and 2 are the farthest advanced by a long ways of 
any of them and you know that is not very far. 
I was somewhat disapointed when I came but was de-
termined to stay one term sure; but further disclose-
ures have rendered that decision of no avail for I 
have made up my mind to leave as soon as I have 
been here long enough to take up all that I have paid 
him. The reasons for my taking this are various; some of 
them are these. I have neither time or money to throw 
away going to school where I shall reap but little 
benefit therefore it behoves me to use them to the best 
advantage and that I cannot do here; they will not 
track grammar if they can avoid it, and only wish the stu-
dents to devote a limited portion of their time to math-
ematics and the chief of it to Philosophy, Physiology, and 
short hand reading and writing. They say that it is a waste 
of time to study grammar and anything but the lower math-

ematics, and that they should devote most of their time
to those other branches, and that will not do for me for I
must and willing study at all study those branches that I shall
have to teach in common schools and those they devote no
attention to at all scarcely. He acknowledges himself that
I am the best writer and reader in fact he is what you
may say neither. There is neither a class in reading or writing in
in school and as for mathematics - oh! [illegible]
I shall leave here ina bout three weeks and shall go to
Peru to see you and if I could get a school I should like it
I do not wish one where the scholars are very far advanced
I do not wish to go on the R.R. or rodsman for I could
not do it without great inconvenience on account of the
pills. I wish to go down and see E. and family but
cannot tell till the time comes whether it would be best or not
as I wish to lose no more time than I can help. I can make
the most of bridging and if nothing else better turns up can
very readily go at that on any road till fall and then I
can get a school without difficulty. Even if you
get a situation for me there (retracted: do not make any calculations
for me to board with you for [illegible] much
pleasure so to do I do not [illegible] with any
more care than she [illegible] it). 
Nevermind the blot I
cannot spend time to write
another letter
do not make any calculations for me
No board with you for although it owuld
give me great pleasure to do I do not
wish to give Jose any more care than she already
has with her feeble health.
Write immediately and [illegible]
J.K.Kendall Patriot - Switzerland Po.
Ind.
Your aff. bro.
J.K.Kendall

Patriot May 21"st / 54

Dear brother Nathan:

           I received your

letter of the 17th last night and should
have answered it ere this had I not
suffered with a sever head ache; and
dear brother in looking back upon the
past history of our family it seems
as though it was particularly visited
with the hand of sickness and trouble
But then without doubt it is all
for the best for each trial that we
bear heavically will only strengthen us
and better fit us for the life
that we shall live where trouble
never comes. I deeply sympatize with 
you in your trouble and wish that
I could render you some kind assist-
ance but it is not in my power
to do so for such is the condition of
my shoulder and health that it
is with the utmost frugality that I
can get along - I shall not stop here

over ten days longer and then I
shall go to Mo. for I feel that I
can do better there than else where; and
that it would be nothing but
throwing away time and money to
stay here and that I cannot do for 
if I should stop here I should have to
borrow about thirty dollars to carry
me through one term and get me
on school and that I cannot afford
to do; and I think that I had
better go to Mo. and get a small
school and then study the way I have
done for the last six months and
the next time I go to any place
go where I am sure of having a
good school Think you not so
dear brother? Remember me very
kindly indeed to Josephine if she is living
and also to David. Do not write
till I write to you where I am

         Your affectionate brother
                      J.K. Kendall

[Jesse to Geo & Sarah Weaver]
Do not show this to Myron
Edwardsville Ill. Feb 13th / 55
Bro. & Sister Weaver!
Your kind
letter written upon the anivers-
ary of my twenty first year
was recieved last night and
both of you asked the question if
I can paused and reflected and
also expressed a wish for me to
do so. And in return I would
say would to God that there was
no such thing as reflections it
nearly drives me crazy oft yes time
after time have I resolved to put
an end to my existence to escape
reflection no one can form
the faintest idea of the conflict-
ing passions within my nature
And none who only see me in my
wild rotuine before the public

will beleive that I am ever sad
still night after night have
I walked the room or laid and
thought of my past life and
formed resolutions for the future
and prayed yes how earnestly have
I prayed for strength to withstand
the temptations that surround
me at present and overcome
the habits that influences of
my boyhood brought upon me
and in less than 10 minutes 
after have I found myself
breathing forth the worst
curses upon myself for be-
ing such a fool upon God
for still continuing my life
and upon those that had the
forming of my character after
leaving my sainted mothers in-
fluence. You say that it is
well for us to look forward
to the future. I have looked
forward to the future and
back upon the past until
all hope is dead within me
and I would candidly and
sincerely rather die more than
to live longer for life has no

charms for me. Bro. W. you
would not wonder at my not
always meeting your wishes
could you but know the war
that has at times go on with-
in me between duty and 
habit And all hope of shining
in the world is dead
(Could I be placed)
my whole moral nature is the
same could I be placed entirely
out of the reach of such tempt-
tions as my past life has been 
surrounded on in the society
of none but such as you and
your wife again they might
get the ascendency and I might
be of use to the world but
otherwise the thing is impossi-
ble. This is my great object in going
East. The truth has at length been
forced upon me that at my track
or any other laborious occupation I cannot earn a livelihood on
account of my back shoulder side
and kidneys one severe days work will
lay me up for a week and there
has not been an hour the past winter
that I have been free from pain in
in my shoulder or kidneys

the longest that I have worked at any
one time since the 9th of last Nov.
is two days and a half and I have
had to have clothes medicine and
board since then so that I am ni
debt about $23. but I have got $12.90
coming to me (my winter's wages)
which I cannot get yet but as soon as
I am out of debt I shall leave this plac
and as soon as I can earn the means I
shall go East and there get a better
education or die in the attempt
I have not written this to get any
sympathy on your part but as 
the candid statement of my
feelings for the past 18 months
As ever
Jesse

Address Edwardsville Madison Co Ill.
Edwardsville March 12 / 55
Dear Brother Nathan
It has been my 
aim for the past two years
to go East for the purpose of
trying to recruit up my
health and also because it affords
better facillities for getting on
[illegible]. One year ago next
April I should  gone and in 
all probability should have by
this time made considerable ad-
vancement ere this instead of 
being so low both physically 
and pecuniarily had it not been that
Sister wished me to go to Ind.
and how I succeeded there and

also found thing you already
know. Now Sister thinks that
it would be best for me
to go East but I dislike
much to go upon other
expense though judging from
the past year if I do not
go that way I shall never go
at all. I am completely discour-
aged My fall from the 
bridge has 
left me in such a situation
that I cannot support myself
by labor and I am not
sufficiently acquainted with
the English Branches or good
enough in penmanship to 
teach school and a broken arm
a cut foot and a scoundal for
a pay master have taken my
fall wages and what little I have

earned in the past five weeks
and left me about $23 in
debt though if I had what
was coming to me in this
place I should be about square
with it here doctors bill and
all. If I have good luck I shall
be out of debt by the first of
May here if I do not get
anything that is coming
to me non which I do not
expect to get and then it
would give me great pleasure
to start to school and I think
that it would be the best
to go East as if I wait till
fall it will take a smal
fortune to support me through 
the winter if we judge the fu-
ture by the past. Were it not for
that I would think of going to

Galesburg but as it is I
think that it would be
the cheapest in the end to go
East and if you will let me
have means enough to get there
and go to school one quarter
I will give you my note
with interest until I can
pay it and I think that one
quarter will put me so that I 
can teach and with teaching
[illegible] working three and going
to school six months in the year I can put myself
for a No 1 teacher in time
About the profession we will
talk when we see each other but
it is either a teacher or minister
Remember me to D and should my
views meet your aprobation I
think that I shall be free by the
first of May if I can keep the
place I now have
Your affectionate brother
Jesse

Chicago, Ill. April 6th / 55
Dear bro. Nathan!
I have just arrived at this place this
evening and at Peoria last
night when the boat was launching I had my pocket
book and $8,50 taken from 
my pocket but I had
$5,10 in my vest which paid
my night's lodging and
fare to this place and
thus was all I have not
a cent left and shall have
to borrow some to pay the
postage on this letter the only
house that I could stop at after

telling them my sotry
is the Sherman and I
have to pay $2,00 per day
so that it will please me
much if you will send 
me some money immedi-
ately as I cannot afford to
pay such bills please send
only enough to what you
think will pay my fare
to LaPorte and my bill
at this House.
Your aff. bro Jesse
Direct - J.K.Kendall
Chicago Ill.

Townshend, Vt - June 20 / 55
Dear brother Nathan
As much as
I dislike to appeal to others
for pecuniary [illegible] I am compelled
to by necessity as my coat is
through at the elbows as well
as in several other places on the
arms and also my shirt have
given out so that I have now
but two which makes hardly
a change I had hoped that they
would last me by careful
useage until I could earn enough
vacation to replace them with
others but so they have been
worn since one year last March
they are nearly done. My disease and
all has cost me more I think than
a whole year of schooling clothes and
all will after this. Am learning in
every thing has Algebra far beyond
my expectations on my Equations in
that but cannot understand it
as thoroughly as I wish in fact can
not see as it will be of any

practical use made myself
sick studying late a few days ago
so than was out of school four days
but am careful now pardon shortness
as it is twenty minutes to [illegible]
and as soon as I am strong again
will write you a long letter all
about myself thoughts feelings
and the like-
Love to David Respects to Mr.
Gleason & Lucy -
Bro Jesse
N.B. Tell E. L. Bennet that
Hellen M. Weaver is in Concord
N.H. but she will get a letter
if directed to Papermill Villiage
N.H. either - Jesse

Townshend Vt. July 8 / 55
Dear Brother Nathan
I received
your last with ten dollars
enclosed last Tuesday and
should have answered it ere
this had it not been that
I had to go over the moun-
tain with the sherif and
did not return until last
night you see last sabath
eve the sherif came to me 
and wished me to guard a
prisoner or rather two of them
that were here and I thought
that it would be a good way

to make a dime and
went thinking that should
be through in the morning
but instead of that had to
go with him to take them
to train and then to jail
there was no school here this
week and there was a celebration
here am going to Brattle-
boro tomorrow to see if I can
not get a situation to work
with or the Carpenters trade or in
a shop as I cannot work 
on a farm in the sun With
the exception of the pills my
health is good. I received a let-
ter from sister Lillie also one
from sister Sarah at the same 
time I received yours both of
which I must answer today Lillie
stated that Myron's leg was not
[illegible] any but rather growing
worse poor fellow I fear he will
loose it entirely Also that I

had the ague and that
also you was in a condition
that she feared would bring
on bleeding again. Now brother
if such a thing should take place 
are you not robbing yourself
to help me? I cannot consent
to your assisting me more than
to put me square here now and
if I get a situation which I think
I can do I can then assist myself
and work along and get an edu-
cation I think if I work this fall
that I can by studying get a small
school to teach in the winter
and so by another winter be able
to teach a larger and what say
you to that. Shall in my next
give you an account of my expenses
here would now but for wont of
time
Your aff. Brother,
Jesse

[1855?]
Constitution O. May 14th / 57 [?]
Dear brother Nathan!
It has been
so long since I have addressed
a letter to you that the 
commencement of this
seems as though I was
writing you for the
first time but never
again as long as my
arm is able to weild 
a pen shall I let another

such a space lapse
without writing you.
My meeting with you
called up feelings that
had been entire strangers
to me before. Oft times 
and more especially the
past fall and winter
have I thought when "in
a fit of the blues" that
I had no one that cared 
for me but when I
met you and felt
the warm and hearty
shake of your hand a 
mere train of feeling
was awakened within
me as the thought
rushed through my mind
thank God I have a warm
and devoted friend and

brother and for the
first time I experienced
a warm and brotherly
affection glow within
me for though I thought
of my brothers more than
I did of my associates
still I hardly ever saw
the time when I cared 
much to see them. Twice
to day have the tears
started when I have thought
what pain my coolness
must have caused my
brothers & sisters. I have
in the morning for
Athens. Co. to be gone some
tend days. Have been settle-
ing up today and find
that it will take me
about five weeks to get
all paid up as I boarded

with Mr. Bailey longer
than I thought I had
and yesterday was obli-
ged to pay that bill of
mine dollars to prevent
a [illegible] of which I was
telling you -
My love to Lillie & Myron
Your Aff. bro,
Jesse

Townshend, Vt July 22 / 55
Dear Brother Nathan
I received
your kind memento of
brotherly affection dated July 1
Friday I had been for the
week before anxious to 
hear from you as I had
a letter from sister L. &
she stated that she was fear-
ful that you would have
another severe attack of
hemorrage of the lungs
and was fearful myself
that it would terminate
fatally but am truly thank

full that it did not
I have formed a plan for
after life and I will
tell it you and my reasons
I think of taking up
latin when I again com-
mence school after this
term and stop Algebra
for I feel that my time
as I cannot understand it at all yet
is thrown away upon that &
continue Arithmetic, Grammer
and the like until I per-
fect myself in them but
still continue on in latin
by myself in connection
with reading medicine with
some one as I am the best adapt
ted for that of any profession
I think and also the most ad-
vanced in it. What to do
about going to school this fall
I do not know. I will tell you
how it is and leave it to you
to decide I think that in the

autumn term I could perfect
myself in Arithmetic and
Grammer as he is going ot
depart from his regular courses
for this fall term and have
a class in Green[illegible] National
Arithmatic and Greenes
Analysis and am confident
that now I have got started
could finish up in those two
branches as could learn as
much in the fall term as I could
in one and half terms often
stopping and as is is now I
dare not take a school in the
Winter as I am not capable
of marking a large number of
the examples in Adams Arith.
But then if I stop here it
will put me in [illegible] deeply
and is a measure inconven-
ience you so that it is all left
to you to say what do. The
way that I stand [illegible] now is that

I am up doctors bill and all
with the exception of clothing I
was forced to run in debt for
a coat $14.50 and if you should
not think best to have me stop
in the fall I
would like to have you let me
have enough to cancel them as I
promised it to him the last of
this month other clothing I will
try and raise this summer vaca-
tion if I should go in the autumn
Never I should not wish with the
exception of the above any, until
the middle of Nov next
Now then bro. you see the way it
is and use your own judgement
and I will be governed accordingly
Love to David Respects to G. & Lady
Your aff bro Jesse

Townshend Vt. Aug 20th / 55
Dear Brother
I received yours
of Aug 12 today and should
have written ere this concern
ing the new arrival of yours
containing $15 had not I
thought to wait and see
if it did not come as the
P.M. thought it might 
have been miscarried and
had also written the P.M.
of your place so that I

thought you would
know of it as soon as
though I should write
and so have waited to
see if it would not come
but it has not the P.M.
is going to write to the
P.M. of your place to day 
so that you can see that 
also if you wish I suppose
I could not work hazing
this summer on account
of the pills I bought me
scythes, whetstone & a smaythe 
but did not work enough
to earn as much as I paid
for them since then have tried
to get a job of work as my
trade here but only have succeed-
ed enough to earn $ four
dollars with that am going
to start tomorrow morning
to [illegible] work have tried all
around here from Brottleboro

to the Falls and have not
as yet found any thing to
do and now am going down
into Northfield and South
Orange to see if can find any
will write you how I succeed
on the subject of going to
school this fall have
given that up as am
now going to earn money
and then go and then
there will be no chance
for the mail robbers to
injure me at least am
oweing more here five weeks

& four days board besides

the coat and conclude that
that is enough for once until
I go to work so am going 
to do so and see if there is
any truth in the saying that
a truly great man is not
easily put down I would
suggest that as the express

comes here as well as at
LaPorte you would put
the money in a letter or
package and send it that
way I think that it would
be the cheapest in the [illegible]
as then if it is lost they
are responsible for the amt
while by registering a letter
it is only an advertisement
to assist thieves to steal
the more readily and creates
no liability on the part of

Algebra as can not understand it

Kansas April 3d / 59
Bro Nathan If you think that
I am not out here "seeing
the elephant" you ought to
take a short sketch of me
at the present time no
coat, no socks, boots all
wore out, shirt the same
way, back all sun burned
so that the scab will crack
open and bleed on bending
and parts patched with an
old bag hair nor whiskers
trimmed since I left and
you have my daguerreotype.
The next time I come out
anywhere to assist Raymond
shall know it for he has served
me this time a dose [illegible]-
ient for all if I had my 
tool here could do well enough
but I am here and my clothes
and tools in K. City if the boat
had not have sunk should have
had enough to have brought them
here but "its as tis and can't
be no miser[?]

If Myron is sharp and can get
his board in the states he will
stay there for it is more than
he can do here while I was up
at Raymonds place I lived on
pumpkins and milk I have
not eaten any flour for
so long have forgotten all about
it, Money in this part of
the [illegible] is an article once
in use but now obsolete. If
I had not come here and knew
as much as I now know would
never come, would work for
my board in the states first
but I am here and here I am
bound to stop until I can
make a raise of about five
hundred dollars and then I leave
for the states and start a grocery and provision 
store. I am putting up a boat 65 feet
long and 12 feet wide got it all done but
pitching cannot get any money for my work cause
there aren't any it is said by all that have 
seen it to be the best boat in this county it is
of black walnut gunwales missed up as
nice as any piece of work you can find and
bottom dove tailed together have used
[illegible] tools [illegible] up about the Fort
you are near enough acquainted with Raymond
so as to know how his business is here (that is) this
in a perfect bungle from beginning to
end will write more but paper is short
Remember me to David and wife your wife and
Lydia and Myron and kiss the baby for me.
Yours truly J.K.Kendall

Townshend Vt Jan 26th
Dear Brother
I received your kind
letter containing a draft of $50-
I wrote you last evening saying it
had not come but to-nights mail
brought it - It was three days longer
coming than your last - David
is here but leaves to-morrow morn-
ing about thinks he can let me
have some money am sorry to 
be dependent upon my brothers &
hope I may not always be. To-night
we have attended "a concert, by the

Mr Hutchinson & Heath and since
concert have been in to an
Oyster supper so it is quite late
I shall come the northern route
if you have no objections for I can
come so much quicker and 
shall not be obliged to stay
out more than one night if
that is if I come back
by this way for Mr Cook of
this place two weeks since
went from here to Columbus in
about 2 days. Can I go from 
Springfield the same nights that
I start from Phillipston? If so I

should rather travel than stay at
Springfield alone - You may not
be surprised if I do not reach k.
till the 22nd of Feb but shall
try to stand so as to get there
to 19th - [?] 8 is the coldest day we
have had this winter- My love 
to all - Daniel & Augusta I call
[illegible] - Affectionately Lydia -

[Lydia]
Petersham, Mass.
Mr. N. Kendall
Sapt. Cin. P. C. N. Road
La Porte, Ind.

(she that was Pamelia Gates) & May

day washed and Tuesday morning

[illegible]
[illegible]

and found Mr. Wadsworth's people

I do hope you will be able to visit [Illegible town name] Town

Riner Junciton ove rSabbath sent

mediately

them after all and had I a good
