Marietta Ohio Sept 22nd
Dear Sister Abby, 
I fully intended to
have written you a long letter today
as well as one to sister Sarah but
the day is past and the evening nearly
and my intention still unfulfilled.
I did not get your good letter till
the morning I left from Boston and
since I have had no time for
writing I have been very very busy
and never more happy I should
so much have enjoyed staying long-
er in N.E. yet I had run about
so much I had become very tired.
I visited Petersham Rutland Barre

from them. I have read the remainder of the Island
Princess and have all yet out of [illegible]
How is Mrs. Lee? My
love to her - How badly
Mr. Wolher's family must 
feel about Jimmy! [Illegible]
little fellow he is lured
much trouble - little
[illegible] - when he was down
to see me & so happy
& well that would he
[illegible ]lost time. Does
these hard money 
times affect Mr. 
Wolher's prospects any?
Are brothers all as
well as usual? Did
Jan see Mr. Weaver 
is he went home
Suppose Sarah and Corrie
have gone. What is the order
of your exercises
now?

Phillipston, Athol, Orange, Royalstem,
Warwick, Boston, Saratoga Springs &
N. York and am now here with 
many visits before one. I also called
at Templeton & Salem I suppose
David & May have told much
more than it would be possible for
me to write of your home &
all that could interest you of 
N. E. friends. I will try however
and be in readiness to answer all
& as many questions as you may be
pleased to ask. I had a very pleas-
ant trip here after leaving David.
There was an accident occurred between
Pittsburg & Wheeling the day before & we
were the first ones that passed it. I
reached here Saturday A.M. quite to
the surprise of all my friends for they
were not looking for me so soon.
My love to all of brothers & May & Mr. Wolhers
family. Please let me hear from you soon.

I have enjoyed my visit here thus
far very much! Have not been
out any yet only to church but have
received many calls Tell Brother that
Mrs. C Reigner was here yesterday and
says that they have not any of them
heard one word from him since he
was here. Mr. & Mrs. Holden want you
both to come & visit them and all
others will be glad to see you.
Mr. N says he wants to see you very
much. I do so wish I had my paints
& brushes & palette. They have two
very pretty pieces in Gil I want so 
much to copy and should if I only had
my materials I have commenced to
finish that piece of embroidery that 
I had commenced and to finish
and leave it. O! I wish you could
have some of the nice grapes & peaches 

With much love
Lillie

I am enjoying them so much
I do not think I shall come back
for several weeks yet as I suppose
I am not to terah[?] I sometimes wish
I could just step in and see you
all & help myself to a few things I 
want I only care to get back & make
you all a visit and get to St.
Louis to spend the winter. I hope
you will make arrangement to
visit St. Louis & spend sometime
when I go. I think you & Mary had
better make your arrangements to go 
with me & then N & D come for
you what say you & the rest to it?
I go there to spend the winter I expect.
Mrs. Do[illegible] (a sister of Mr. Bennet) was in to see me yesterday
and said she was looking for him here. If
he is coming I would much like to have you
send any materials for painting [illegible materials]
talma & my merino drapes & pieces of them
or at least my light one & its [illegible]
Tell Jesse & Myron I have not heard a word

Kinsdale N.H. Feb 14th
Ever dear Brother -
It is with pleasure that I
now seat myself for the purpose of communi-
cating a few thoughts to you by the silent
language of my pen, as that is the only
means we have at present; but hope to
see you soon. I should have looked for
you and Sister last week if there had been
sleighing; she wrote that you had thought
of coming up. I suppose that she has
closed her school e're this. I have been 
looking for a letter from you for some
time past and concluded that you was
waiting for me to write or some other
reason but think that you owe me one.
Miss Boukes said that she saw you a short
time since she said that you had a 
very pretty school house and very convenient
she spoke of your [illegible] as being first rate
I suppose that you would like to hear
something about my school. I have had 
52 different scholars the average attendance
has been about 48 so far and it is
about what I know how to get along
with I think. My oldest schollar is 13 the
next 11 and so down to 8. I have none

in letters and I am not sorry for that.
I have 7 classes in reading and the same
in spelling one class in Coalburn's Arithmatic
one in Emerson's Arithmetic 2 classes in Mitchels
small geography and several in writing &c &c
I board at Mr. Goodnow's like very much have
a first rate of a room-mate. Miss Johnson,
I have not seen anyone from Chesterfield
since I have been here. Ellen Marsh is
married I received a card from her.
I have seen Mrs L E Jahnson several times
but not to get any aquainted with her. 
I would like to know whether you are
again to teach at Chesterfield or not this
spring, there is several that will go from
here this spring to C if there is a school and I want to go some
where to school or the teachers institute
if I teach next summer. They have sent
a proposal to have it come here do not
know whether it will come or not if it should
or go to Chesterfield I would like to attend
if you do not teach any where near and
think best, wish that you would send
word what you think about it.
I received a letter from Jesse and was much
pleased to think that he could write so well
He wrote that he liked his teacher very much
and what he was attending to for studies &c &c

very much. Mr. & Mrs Good vows respect to you
He said that Grandmother's health was better
than usual and the rest of the people were
well. He wrote that Mother was not very
well would like to hear from her. I suppose
that Sarah Miller is married. We are to
have a temperance lecture from Mr. 
Lealand the honest quaker presume that
you have heard of him. I have attended
Church all day in the morning I went
to the Orthodox and this afternoon to
the Universalist. I have attended several
common school conventions which are
held around in the different districts in
town and enjoy them very much, I have
kept 11 weeks and suppose that i have 4
more to keep. I wish that it was conveni-
ent for me to visit your school think
that you must enjoy yourself very much
for I did. Please give my best respects
to all that inquire for me and to all
my schollars. Ttell Adelphia and Hisk that
I would like to see them very much.
Please write me soon and tell me all 
the news and what you think about my
attending school for it is almost time to
know and as it is growing dark I must
draw to a close. Please excuse all mistakes
and writing and so good night (This from your [illegible]
sister Lydia)
If you see Sarah tell her that I would like to have her send 
me 2 or 3 dollars and if it is convenient for her for I want some

Hinsdale NH
July 15 
Mr. Nathan Kendall,
Petersham, MA

Petersham May 6, 1846
Dear Brother,
I now seat myself
to write you a few lines as I promised to do. I arrived
at Phillipston about 2 oclock in the P.M. and found
Mr. Powers to the tarvon[?], he had just brought hartha
out to take the stage and carri[illegible] directly home; 
I had several calls that night and attended meeting
Sarday. Mr. Gorge came for me Monday morning and
I commenced my school with out being examined
but went up at night and came off much
better than I expected for they did not ask me a
question in Arithmetic and in grammer they only
asked me to passe a line and said that if
I could passe that they would risk me, and
they wanted that I should board Massachusetts
and write and that is all. Mr Clark & Mr
Day a gentleman from Connecticut visited the school
yesterday and they left a new kind of a register
and it will take me all the time to
fill it out; and it is against the law to pay
a teacher till it is filled out and returned;
have to have roll call twice a day and put
down the tardy markes and every half day that

a scholar is absent, and the parents & all the
schollar names, and there ages in month and
years and all their studies &c like very much
think that I shall like school teaching, have
some very pretty schollars especily some of the 
small ones. have had about 30 there is
several more that are coming they think that
there will be about 40. The oldest will be 15
come september. have 6 that are 13 some 12 and from
there down to 3. have various kind of studies
which I [illegible] stop the mention now for
I am in a great hury for I am a going to
town and want to put this in the Ofice.
Mother health is very good excepting her 
head troubles her very much she does not know
whether she shall go out to Albany or not send
her love to you and Myron also[?] Mr. Younge sends
his best respects to you and says that you shall
have a new school house before another winter
they have sold the old one and spoke for a new 
one. I have a very good boarding place it is
with K W Howe and his sister. Tell Ellen that 
I board with an old Bacholar and maid but
they don't look much like Foster. give my best
respects to all of Mr Mead folks and tell them
that I would like to see them. tell the
girls that I shall write them soon give my best
respects to all that takes the pains to inquire

for me &c &c. Tell Mr Mead that I guess that
the people are jewes for they keep me very well.
Miss Howe sayes that she wants that I should
tell you that they do not live where they use
to or it's much pleasanter than it was there
they live where jaeson Lamb's folk li'd and she
would like to have you come this summer
and see us. Wish that I could stop in to chs[?]
Meads once in a while and see some of the Chesterfield
people hope that you enjoy yourself now. Pleas
excuse all mistakes and the writing for I have written as fast
as I could for I am in a good hury. Write soon 
and write all farhenlars[?] pleas accept this from 
Lydia Y Kendall
Good night
to Nathan Kendall

Mr Nathan Kendall
Chesterfield
N H

Petersham June 14 1846
Beloved & Absent Brother,
At your request I now
seat myself to write a few lines to you to give you
a sketch of my school and to let you know where
mother is &c. I was at mothers last monday short
time after school and had a very pleasant time. she
was preparing to start for Albany wednesday. suppose that
she is there ere this. Myron stays at Cheney's
I expect. The people were all well I believe with the 
exception of cousin Rebecca who has been oblidged to leave
her school on account of her limb which has troubled
her very much. it is not the one that has troubled her
before. She does not know of hurting it any way but
the doctor thinks that it is humors that settle in them.
she has been with Dr. Kitchridge the same one
that she has been with before. Mother had a letter
from Edwin he was well and attends school at Ludlow
this summer. Sarah is at Townsend Mass suppose that
you know all that about her and so I will omit saying
more about her. Raymond I suppose that you know is at
Norwich University. David is at Mr. Richardsons this summer
likes very well I believe have not seen him yet. have had
a letter from Mary & Laura and was very glad to see 
it they said that Luertha Ellen and Charlotte did not

get a recommend to keep school this summer should think that
they would feel rather bad about it I have written
to Ellen but she has not answered it and don't think
that she will but can have her own time to do it
in. You did not say one word about them and you
promised to write whether they ever said any more about
that fuss or not. Mary says that there are very still[?] times at
Chesterfield the most so that she ever knew them.
Mr. Fulson has left & there has been a dentist a boarding
there since we left and that is about all that I
can tell you about Chesterfield now. I will try and give 
you a little discriptions of my school I have had 38.
school and there are two others girls a coming now
believe that I wrote what the studies were before. My
first class is Arithmetic have got through inspection.
think that they have got along very well. the second
class have got to multiplication of compound numbers
they have all done the sums out on the board and I
think that they understand them well. have not had any
trouble yet nor had to punish or do any thing yet but 
speak and do not think that I shall. Warren Houghton
George Rickery Kirk White and George Bruce are the largest
boys that I have. like very much. much better than I
expected and should like very much if Ihad a different
boarding place but have got half done I suppose, think
that if I was a going to keep again I should have
a word to say if I had got to board here again but don't
know Miss Pratt the one that taught more at Townsend is

at Petersham now have got considerable aquainted with
her. I have had a tooth out since I came here I had
the tooth ache a last a fortnite and then I thought it
time to stop it. Martha Upton has had her teeth put in
and you can not tell how much better it makes her look.
Dr. Holland is here yet and thinks of staying this
summer and working at haying &c. Abby Eates and Father
start for the West to-morrow to begin three or four weeks.
and as I can not think of much more to write I will
close soon the people send their best respects to you and
say they would like to see you give my best respects
to Chesterfield people if you see any of them before
I do if they inquire for me and much love to your [illegible]
please accept this from your sister. but one thing more
I would like to have you explain out inspection when [you]
write and I will be very much oblidged to you. Uncle Lamb,
people have moved down beside Mr Stalls people think
that I shall go down there to morrow if nothing happens.
have been to Borre once since I came here and they said
any time that I wanted to come they would send for
me they are very anxious that I should come back there
this winter but I would rather keep school if I could
but don't know as I can get one. wish if you could that 
you would engage one for me and so good bye for now
write often and don't let any one see this for it looks
so bad
{From Lydia Y Kendall)
(To Nathan Kendall)

[Lydia 1846]
[Petersham MA JUN 16]
Mr Nathan Kendall
Townsend
Vt

Petersham June 20th
Ever dear Brother
I now seat myself for
the purpose of answering your kind epistle
of May 30th perhaps you may think
strange that I have not done so before
but my time has been so much taken up
with my school that I could not. Last week
went home and spent the sabbath found the
people all well with the exception of Edwin
but he is better. Mother gets along very well
and enjoys her-self. Grand-father has been gone
till yesterday he returned do not know
what he is a going to do. C. Baldwin and
Mary Powers are married also James Smith and
Eunis Haven. Father and Marshall have
been moved. Cousin Rebecca has been
disappointed about her school she has but
6 weeks she feels rather bad about it, and
now I will try and give you a short sketch
of my school. I have had 35 schollars for studies
I have Arithmetic B classes in Adams the
first class with the exception of Misey have got
to the 185[?] page they have done most of the
sums on the board from the commencement

of the book and understand them well.
Mary Hapgood and Luthesa Wane got to
the 91 page get along very well. My next
class went to division and then I had them
go back they have got about there again.
Coalburns I have had 3 classes the first have
finished through and so I have but 2. Emerson
1 Grammar 3 classes History 1 Mitchel's Geography,
2 classes in the large and in the small.
Natural Philosophy 1 Watts on the mind 1.
I have 18 that write, have them write every
other day. I have 6 that write Composition
every week. The first class use the American
header, the second the Grammer school Reader
it is a new book the third Mount Vermont
and 10 that just begin to read and 4 that
never went to school before &c &c and now
you may judge whether I have any thing
to [illegible] or not. Martha Gates is very sick with
the Billious fever. she was taken last week.
Kirk has had to stay out of school with his
throat he is better now they think of going to
Worcester to have the bunches taken out. they 
raised their barn yesterday. Mr. Bryant says
you ought to have your Policy if you are sick.
Catherine is teaching where Maria was agoing
to, gets along well. Maria and E_ have gone to 
Con_.  I had a letter last week from Sarah
and she said that she had not heard from you

since you went to Townshend and would like to.
she was well. Raymond will be at home in July
think tha tyou will have a very good school
here this fall. You wished me to send you some
money and I would be happy to do so if I had it
but I let Edwin have all that I had to spare - 
I told him and he said that he would get
some if he could and send you perhaps you have
heard from him ere this. I will let you have some
as soon as my school is through if you wish if 
E. does not send you any. Please write often
and excuse all mistakes. What a rainy day it is
so wet that we do not any of us go to church.
I forgot to tell you where I board I am at
Mr C. Gates like very much as well as [illegible]
place that I was boarded at and as I can 
not think of any thing that will interest 
you I will draw to a clase by biding yoy
good bye. The people all send their best respects
Please from your loving sister Lydia.
(To Mr Nathan Kendall)

[PETERSHAM MASS, JUNE 21]
Mr. Nathan Kendall,
Townshend, Vt.

Phillipston Oct 25th 46
Beloved Brother,
I now seat myself to scribble
a few lines to you. I have been looking for
a letter for sometime past but have been disappointed 
as yet. I closed my school 5 weeks ago yesterday
and have been at mothers most of the time
since. I have been at Barre, cousin Agusta went
with me. Have been at Petersham once since
I left, and Catherine Houghton has been over
here once. they are haveing a new school house
built I expect. I spent last week with Agusta
and enjoyed myself very much Ebeckah has gone
to Townsend again her limb gains very fast now.
Sophia is attending school in town. Sarah Cheney
commence a school in Heath Ms[?] the first of November.
Roena is at home now. Isabella Miller is married and
gone off and Sarah is a fixing to also. Cousin Emeline
and John Frye were down last week the poeple were all
well. I should have gone home with them if I had
known when my school commenced. Jesse was at home
4 weeks ago and has not grown very much - James Cutting
has been repairing his house and out buildings and
you would hardly know the place, he has him a new
house and Carriage &c &c and people begin to say
that they think there is something to happen yet

but don't know how that is. Aunt Lamb has been quite
sick but is better. Cousin Agusta has been quite sick but
is quite smart now. I was sick the week after my school
finished and had a fine time a few days but got better
in a short time so that will cost me a dollar or too.
I ahve heard from sister once and suppose that you
have the same but she did not write anything in
particular about that school, and I would like to have
you write me when it commences for I do not know any 
thing only what you wrote me and shall not go or do
anything about it till I hear something more. would
like to have you write me as soon as you get this in
regard to that school for I would like to stop at Winchester
at Leonards 2 or 3 days if it is convenient and
would like to see you there or at Hinsdale if you do not
come home before. You wrote that Mary and Leonra were 
going to write but have not seen anything that looked
like a letter from them. Please give my best respect to all 
of Mr. Meads people and to all that inquire for me
tell Mr Meads people that I would be happy to see
them at Hinsdale this winter and I shall depend
upon a visit from Mary and Leonra. I was very glad
to hear that you had so good a school and would
liked to have been among the number but it was
ordered to be otherwise and so I was denied the privelge 
and as it is all most Church time I must close.
The people all send there love with me to you and
Sophia and Agusta say that they shall be very glad
to have your school finish for they want to see you

very much and as I am in a hurry you must take
this and correct and excuse it and write soon so good bye.
(To Nathan Kendall) (From your affectionate 
Sister Lydia Y Kendall)

[Lydia to Nathan]
Phillipston MA
Oct 27
Mr. Nathan Kendall,
Chesterfield, N.H.
(Please forward)

Rutland May 28 1848
Dear Brother-
As you requested me to let you hear
from me today I will endeavor to comply with your 
request. After you left I went up and was examined
commenced my school tuesday main have 42 scholars.
there are 4 or 5 more that are coming in tomorrow
I have 2 boys 16th yrs also 4 girls 14 almost 15 several boys
and girls 12 and 13 ys old &c. I like my school very well;
for stuies I have Adams, Coalburns, Smith, and
Emersons Arithmatics, Mitchels large and small Geogra-
phy and Poileys Grammer and History &c
I staed at Mr. Thayers till wednesday night like them very
much I have a good boarding place with the exception
of the distance. I did not teach yesterday went to Worcester
and had my dresses [illegible]. I met Charles and Merian
Bouter, I have not been at church to day on account

of my bonnet. Mr Rice says that he will find horse and
buggie for Mrs Rice and myself to go to Phillipston the
first day my school does not keep think that I shall
come in 4 or 5 weeks if the weather is pleasant I left several
things at home that I want Give my love to all the people
tell Edgar and Marshall that I want to see them very much
and as I cannot think of anything more to write I will
stop by the way tell Augusta I have found her card
among my things also Sophia small ring was in my box
will bring them home when I come. write me soon
and tell us how Miss Davis does. whether Locah Sanderson
is teaching &c how you get along and the boys and
Sarah &c. Have you heard from mother again. write
soon. (Please excuse all)
This from your affectionate sister
Lydia

[Lydia 1848]
[Rutland MA, MAY 30]
Mr. Nathan Kendall
Phillipston, Mas

Phillipston, Mass Jan 21 1849
Much loved Brother-
I recieved your kind epistle in due season
and was very glad to see it. I had given up all hopes of
hearing from you but was happily disappointed. I have
commenced to write to several times but have not
finished for want of time then they would lay so long
that I would commence again. Mother received a letter from
you last week. I received a circular from sister, was glad
to see that you prospered so well in school concluded you
was well as you said nothing in respect to it. I should have
written to you longere this had not my evenings all been occupied
I have to spend 1 or 2 at the school house every week
with my Arithmetic classes &c. I am at Dist No 5
as I suppose you already know and heard with cousin Mary.
My school consists of 28 scholars the oldest 18 yrs youngest 4 yrs of
age I have had no trouble as yet and hope for none. I have kept
9 weeks and have about 4 weeks longer I suppose. I do not know
what I shall do in the spring I shall not attend school I think
now. I sometimes think that I shall not try to go much
more for it costs as much as I can make about as much
teaching common schools. Jesse does not take hold of
his studies as I wish he would he is to wild for his own
interest but I hope as he grows older he will sober down-
Mother's health is very good as a general thing for her.
Erasmus's people are quite well they have a very pretty
babe. Marshall grows quite fast and Edgar same he has

has been to school some he likes it very much he can read
some and spells quite well. Myron lives with Mother and
goes to school. The school is kept by Miss Elvira Dunn of 
Petersham, Districts No 1, 3, and 7 have had considerable
trouble this winter. The school at Sedgeville is kept by Mr.
F.Jones of Sthol they say he is quite a favorite among
the ladies. Lymon White has given very good satisfaction
as teacher - Sarah Sanderson has given good satisfaction
as a teacher so far she has closed her school she was
teaching when she wrong you and commenced another
in the Dis_ she taught in last summer. Henry has given
up going to school for the present.
Tell Sarah that she has lost Jathum[?] Bigelow for he is married
to Lucy Covell. Mr. Asa Bates and Mr. Stockwell also Mrs Charles
Baker have died lately... Mr Josiah Bouker is very sick and
they think him dangerous. Aunt Lamb is getting along
slowly. Elvira Wetherell is married. John Howe has moved
to the middle of Petersham. Sylvanus Howe has failed.
Permelia Gates has recovered from her crazyness and come home
Edwin ges along very well with his school he thinks he shall
not keep after this winter. Franklin Brown is at Boston
this winter. Mary & Sophia are at home Mary likes teaching
very much. Joseph recommends for Mary and myself
to go to California to teach thinks we might get some of
the gold for pay. I visited Petersham the 13th and spent
the evening at Browns had a great time wished you 
there. Joseph thought you would enjoy playing whist
we had three or four games at that. They are all well at P.

The Ladies Fair was held in the vestry on the 10 of this month
They received $140 by it. the grab bag pracured them $14 letters
were $10 Sarah Cheney was post master. the privilege of putting
the hand in the grab bag was $.125 tickets $.25 &c. The tables
looked finely. There was a good many fancy astielas[?] they sold 
well. James Cutting is quite still this winter he has not
asked any of his cousins to ride out with him since last
fall Sarah Cheney went to Petersham she thought it would
finish her going with him. Tell Sarah that I had to
pay $.75 for the use of the watch that I had of him last
winter so that is worse than she had to do.
They are quite still here this winter to what they were last
They started a ride but was obliged to give it up on account
of rain [illegible] have had a great supply of snow here for a 
few weeks [illegible] week before last they were obliged to brea[illegible]
roads twice a day to get to the school house and back a[illegible]
then we went with the oxen one day a part of the scholars
could not get there. The weather has been very cold much
colder than for past winters. Almeda Rich is married
to Albert Farr they live in the house opposite the school
house the one occupied by his father at the time Sarah
was at Athol. They were published last yr and not married
and so was obliged to be published the second time
They sent their lane[?] to Larek[?]. Sophia Kendall has
been teaching at Templeton in the ois[?] you kept in
she classes this week. Augusta is at Shelburne teaching
Sarah Cheney is at Petersham. Roena is at Boston Mr.
(the priest) Wilson is teaching at the west of Petersham Lason Tower
helps him. You spoke of the many happy hours we have spent

together & do I think of them but they have fled ne'er to return
would that we might spend more together but I often think that
we may not be allowed the privilege. I sometimes think that
I have passed my happiest hours but hope whispers back ahead
If there is any danger of the colera you will come home will you
not? I do not know where I shall go when I finish here.
Jan 24
Mr Nathan Kendall
Mt Washington, Ky
Bullit Co.
(via Boston & Louisville)
You will please write often will you not? I began to think that you 
was agoing to be as decible as Raymond. Give much love to Sarah
Wilson and Mary sends their love to you both and presume
others would if they knew. I was writing. Mr and Mrs Collins & J Lanering
sends their respects. You are inquired after often Jesse sends
love. write often and soon don't follow my example
This from your loveing sister Lydia. my pen is very coarse
as I suppose you have already found.

Petersham Dec 8th 1850
My Dear Brother
I ment to have written
last week to you but time and circumstance
forbid - I commenced my school last
Monday morn like it quite well have
but 18 scholars. I am "boarding around"
this winter for the sake of lengthning
out the school - My home is at Mr
Stevens I have my washing and ironing
done and stay over Sabbath there which makes
it much pleasanter for me -
I was very sorry to hear that Miss Weaver
had been so unfortunate it must
make it very unpleasant for her
being sick so far from her friends.
I am very glad that you have chosen

a profession for I feel quite anxious
for some of the older boys to get
through - It seems as if Edwin had
been a long time about his.
David has gone back to Townshend this
winter to attend school he thinks for
the last time he made very good
improvement during the Autumn
I should think Mother's health is
very good and hope it may remain
so. Myron goes to school to Mr. E S. Fish.
Sarah Cheney teachers No 5 school. Augusta
Kendall No 6 Elizabeth Brown No 2 at 
Phillipston. Cousin J.B.K. was up a short-
time since he is doing very well wished to be remembered to you - Edwin teaches
at West Townshend. Capt Hastings met
with a sad accident yesterday while en-
gaged at work in Mr. A Bryant's tanshop
he was caught in some of the machinery
and broke his arm and ancle. Asenath
Williams (Mrs. F Brown's sister) about three
weeks since as she went to jump from
a carriage her ancle came out of
the socket and broke so that it can into the ground

two or three inches - they think her life
doubtful if she recovers she has got to
lose her limb - It seems very sad - 
Miss Jane Bryant & Maria Farsow are
married. Adelphia they say is going
to be. I had a letter from Sarah and
Jesse a few days since. Jesse says he is
going to teach this winter am quite
fearful for his success but hope he will
succeed well - Frank White is teaching - 
The people hear are all inquiring for
you. Do you intend staying where you
are and studying after you get [illegible]
wish you could be nearer home [illegible]
very happy to hear that there is a pros-
ect of your regaining your health again
hope you will be very careful of your
self. My health is very good indeed.
You must excuse more for my ideas
are quite dull to night as usual and
my head aches. Every district in Mass
have been presented with Websters
large Dictionary quite a present is
it not? Write soon
Affectionately L. Y. Kendall

[Petersham Mass.
Dec 9]
Mr. Nathan Kendall
Mount Washington, Ky
Bullit Co.
(via Boston & Louisville)
[Lydia 1850]

Phillipston Nov 3 50
My Dear Brother Nathan
Your very kind
and interesting epistle reached here by regular
course of mail togather with one from
Sister Sarah but I being gone did not
have the pleasure of perusing them for
nearly a week but I truly enjoyed it
then - We were very happy to here that your
health was pretty good and hope it may
remain so - you must be very carefull
of yourself - Sarah writes thus she misses
your society so much but likes the place
society manners & customs of th epeople
much better than at Mt Washington
but for all that is not as happy or regards
her own private feelings as when with you
I think that she is laboring much harder
than she ought.
I suppose you know that Erasmus is at 
LaFayette Ind since I last wrote you
I have received two letters from him he
says that he has written you several times
this summer but has had not answer.
the letters did not reach you perhaps on
account of the eross[?] routes - he seems to
be in very good spirits - although badly afflicted 
[written along the side]
We've gotten a new clock - S. A. Sanderson sends her respects.

with the fever & ague hope he will soon
be free from it - I had a letter last week from Edwin
& David they are well - you do not know
how lonely I felt at first when the boys
all but Myron were gone so far I have
never been left before without some of my
elder brothers never when I was at home.
I have not been away from home for more
than a yr to be gone more than a week
at a time something new for me is it not?
but have not been at home more than 
4 week at a time since I closed my school -
Mr. Baldwin has been for me to take No 5
school again since I engaged at Petersham
Mr. Ira Neaten was burried last week -
Hoshell Dunton died last night. Dr Pockurd
has burried his daughter Mrs Hoshell that was south.
Jane Bryant is to be married soon also Adelphia
Mr Weeds house &c are to be sold the 9th of
this month - Frank White is going to teach 
this winter - Cousin J. B. Kendall I saw
last week he appeared finely and is doing
well he inquired for you and asked to be
remembered to you his wife's health is very poor
Augusta came home last week came home with 
me at noon wished you and the remainder of
the cousins here - she sends her love - E. Wilson 
teaches at Petersham the first Dist. from her
fathers she & Nathan send their respects to you
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Is there much said what "the spiritual kno kings"among the 
people there - It is producing great excitement about here in ple[illegible]
where it has been heard especially at Artol Charleston Springfield
and others that I've seen have been there - J. B. asked for the
spirits of his Mother & Brother and sister and was responded too
and also as was Linnber[?] of other questions. There was this
different persons present the night she was in. The ministers of
Athol were in. It is something that seems very singular certainly
persume you have seen all about it in the papers for there 
has been a good deal said in the papers this way -

Mr. Weaver helped sister with her letter
seems to think very much of my good
sister as well as brothers. I think Miss
Weaver must feel very lonely being so far
from her friends & home and fidning the
society so different from that she has been
acustomed to associate with - Please give her 
my respects -
Mr. W A Eatons boy that now lives with him
is going from there to a [illegible] next spring
and perhaps he would take Myron for one
or two yrs do not know - what do you think
of it? Myron has been there some for both summers
back  and likes very well - Do not know of any other
place so good for him - Will see him or [illegible]
David about it if you think best for her must
have a place another yer - Please write what you
think. Do you not think it best for us to live
somewhere we could have employment
and board at home. D could get work
enough in most any village & Nathan could
have sewing and so could I when not in school?
we can not earn anything braiding as low as hats
are now - Wish you was at home - Mother &
Myron - Sarah & Roena & Dr. Stones folks & Mr
Millers folks join in sending their love to you - Mother's
respects to Miss Weaver - Please write soon -
We have very little more ink left but my
pen has abled me to use considerable & is forming
the impossibilities to get any good pens at the present
[written along the side]
Please pardon all amiss and receive this kindly
from Affectionate sister Lydia

[Phillipston M. S Nov 5]
Mr Nathan Kendall
Mt Washington, Bullitt Co, Ky.
(via Boston & Louisville)

[note written on top in different handwriting from the letter]
if it wasn't for Lydia I would copy mine over
Myron
tell Nathan and Jesse to write Raymond who
(to Sister Sarah)
(from Myron)
Phillipston March 9th 1851
My dearly loved brother
It is just three
months since I last wrote you and most
six weeks since I received your last for delaying
to answer which I must beg your pardon.
I was sick so as to be out of school from the
13th of Dec till the 30th with the "throat
ail" rash and something of the scarlet fever
as I my joints troubled me much which
was the effect of my scrofula. I had not
set up all day when I went into school and
my limbs being very weak it caused scrof-
ulous bunches and swelling. The Dr says it
is often the case with those of serofulous
constitutions to be afflicted in this way
after having the scarlet fever - He says he
thinks when the weather becomes settled
they may be better though they may
trouble me a year or more. I am taking
iodine now but am going to takeing
cod liver oil and so is Mother - I do not

walk any except a very short little about house
for they think it better that I should not
My limbs were worse after my school closed
for I used them to hard at examination
but are on the gain now I think - 
Was sorry to hear you were so unwell you did
not say one word in regard to your health
in Mothers letter, are you better? Would
like to have gone with you to visit
Erasmus - Did you find them well and
pleasantly situated? Is he in good spirits 
and doing well? and has he got over the
fever & ague - How were the children? What
do they call their little girl &c &c. I wrote to
him last Autumn and have received no
answer as yet have looked all winter for
one. Am sorry you were so unfortunate
in having your school broken up. I shall
be very glad when you and Edwin get through
with your studies ready to practice - Expect
Edwin at home this week do not know
what he is going to do nor did he
the last time he wrote Mother. You say he
has not written you for a long time he has
not written to me since last Autumn
till then he used to write one in fortnight
or oftener - David is at Orange with Mr Howe
Think he has improved as much as any person
I ever saw he is one of the best of boys so good

and kind in every thing It has been a great
advantage to him in going to schoola nd it
is seldom you find so good a scholar for
one that has been to school no more than he -
I did not see any of Mr Welds people this winter
for my health was so poor did not go about any.
Mary Jane has been to N.Y. this winter but has
got home I believe. Joseph Wilson & Mr Tidd
bought their place and C. H. Weatherell bid
off the right of redemption which was worth
nothing. Mr Weld has not been at church
more than once if that since you were here
Sarah Sanderson is at Hopkinton and is to stay
till Winter again with Elira she attends school
some - Mary & Sophia are at home have been at
Boston & Lavell and many their friends - One of
Mr. L Yimmy[?]'s children that went to school is
dead - There has been quite a number of accidents
at Petersham this winter - Henry Sanderson is attentive
to Kate Moore. Greenwood to Elvira Richardson.
Sarah Cheney has gone as teacher to Westford
state reform school she is the first female
teacher they have had - Augusta & Sophia are
expecting to go to Charleston I believe Ellen
Wilson is at home - We had quite a snow storm
here yesterday but the snow is nearly gone - We
have had a great deal of snow till within 3 or 4
weeks the ground has become entirely bear. We are
to stay here another yr if we wish - I think I shall
teach this summer now should not did not

necessity compels me so to do - If I had
the means I should go to Provincetown as the
Drs all advise me to and take sea baths
Think now if Sarah would like to go I shall
in the Autumn if I have a school that is
long and have good pay -
I have been at church today We have had
some very interesting and beautiful discourses
to day wish you might have been here I
have not been at church but a very little
this Winter - You spoke of Dicks work, I have 
seen them and heard them highly spoken of
but have not read them but shall - Wish I
could see you should enjoy it so much
anticipate much pleasure in having you
and Sarah at home oncemore. Please write
as soon as you get this and I will try and not 
be so dilatory in answering in future. My love
to all. Mother and Myron send their love to
you and the rest - From your affectionate sister
L. Y. Kendall
[Written in different handwriting, below the signature of L. Y. Kendall]
Phillipston March 10 1851
Dear Sister
I thought that I would write a
few lines to let you know how I have been doing this
winter. had a verry pleasant school this winter. I went to
2 20th page Arithmetic. I have been trapping a little this
winter have caught three rabbits six red squirrels one flying one
I went to the donation party had a very good time

[Phillipston M. S. Mar 10]
Mr. N. & J. K. Kendall,
Marietta Washington Co Ohio
Via Boston

Phillipston May 4 '51
My fondly loved brother
I received your kind &
long looked for letter yesterday and read it
with pleasure and disappointment for Sarah
wrote that you would tell us all about
Erasmus and family but you said not one
word concerning them except you had
been there. I have heard nothing from them
since the last of Nov (this spot is a tear) but can't help it -  I then write him
but he has never answered it do not know
why for I wished an answer immediately for I put
to paper that Mr Goulding made out of his
affairs into the letter can't see through it.
How are they getting along and enjoying themselves?
Do the children go to school? are they pleasantly
situated? Where shall I direct a letter to him?
[written along the side of the paper]
you asked if the rent was paid is it not I suppose David will see to half and 
Sarah said that when you got back that some of you would send it but
I wrote her that David would pay half and suppose that some of the rest of you 
would pay the rest - If convenient for you over[?] Sarah wish you would see to it
immediately am sorry to ask for any but do not see how to get any
without I have done all that I could 
If I had been well should have paid
it. I have found the wood for one yr
which cost $11 - 2 for the summer and 9
for the winter. I have found the butter
which was from $4 to 5 and a bll of flour
which was $7 and paid Mothers last 
spring Dr bill and a girl for 4 weeks
mother paid her a part though - 
beside I have got Mother some hair for
hers is all gone over very gray and 
several other things - Her Dr. bill for 
now has not been paid but we shall 
one of us see to it - Mother has grown 
to Sarah quite old - she is boy[?] much
broken I think and almost every 
one speaks of it. If you [illegible]ist anyone
to go to P. or else where think it ought
to be Mother - I have thought to go in 
Sept but do not think now that I shall 
if I can get along with out for it asks
so much. R. Millers child is dead
Aunt Susan is very sick with the
Inflamation of the lungs. I must say 
that I had never troubled with the
"Illnes so much as I have been for a 
week past it is seldom they trouble 
me

I want you should write as soon as you
got this and tell us all about them - 
your letter was not mailed till four days
after it was written and Sis lost for a longer time
and that has been the case with all of the lost
letters from there. what is the reason?
Edwin and I sent a letter to Jesse the 7th of Apr and
Mother one to Raymond the 19th and I one to
Sarah the 22nd should have thought they must
have got them before yours was mailed - 
you don't know how much I desire to see you
and Sarah it seems sometimes as if it would
relieve me very much had I any one to talk with
that knew just our situation in pecuniary affairs.
It seems sometimes as if it was next to impossible
for us to get along and keep house for Mothers health
is so poor most of the time that it is not fitting
for her to be alone and I can not earn anything scarcely
more than my board at home - If Sarah had not
been coming home do not believe we should have
tried to have kept house but got Mother boarded.
I ahve earned $100 since last May but have nothing
left last winter and spring there was between 3 & 4
months that mother was not able to do anything scarcely
and this Spring she has been very sick - Her health
is very poor now she seldom sits up all day and can
do nothing hard. She wishes to go up and see uncle
J. Nickerson this summer and I think she will for
I have concluded to teach at South Orange the large
[written on the left side of the page]
Myron has a good place and likes much and I am rejoiced for he is so
much better off - Sarah asked where to direct to S. Cheney it is to The State Reform
School Westbury. The spring is delightful Thing seem quite forward
[written on the right side of the page]
Nathan & Myron join with me in sending love to you all - 
Mrs Wilson & Ellen & Millers folks many others do the same

school. Davied offered to get MOther boarded but
she thought if she could she had rather visit
My school does not commence till the first of June.
My health is good except my limbs and they are better
though they trouble me a good deal now. The bunches
are not gone but they do not swell much. I walk
from here to town though seldom frather - 
Old Mrs. Lavering is dead also Lirrie Browns Foster
Esq Goulding has a son and they feel very much
pleased with it - Mr. Miller came very near getting
killed by his horse week before last he got him down
between his fore legs and took his arm in his mouth
they think the bone is split and then he kicked him
on his head and hip he is getting along very well
though. Aunt Cheney fell down and hurt her quite 
bad so she has not been able to do anything for some
time. The last I heard from cousin Augusta she was 
quite sick - Mr E Bigelow has moved back to town
Sarah is worried - Give my love to Jesse and tell
him I should like to be with him a few days now he's
sick hope he is well though by this time.
I fear Sarah will not be as happy here as she thinks
to be though hope she will her friends will be all very
glad to see her but do not think she will find
the life of a teacher as pleasant as there wish myself
west almost every day. Think I may go sometime - 
Are you not coming home when I comes you have
not said anything about it in your last letters
Do hope you will if it will be as well for you
[written along the side of the page]
Write soon and excuse all amiss and believe me your affectionate sister 
Lydia
Tell Sarah that she may imagine me in one of my "nervous fits, for I can
cry one minute and laugh the next have hardly had such a turn since she and Lera till now

[PHILLIPSTON
May 6]
Mr Nathan Kendall,
Marietta, Washington Co, Ohio
(Via Boston) Please forward.

Lydia Kendall to Nathan 
Postage 10 - [illegible]
May 4 - 5
Phillipston to Marietta
Grand mother not well
Thinking of giving up house keeping
thinks of going to Cape Cod in summer
Jesse in West

[ORANGE, M.S.
JUL 2]
Mr Nathan Kendall,
Marietta, Washington Co., Ohio
(Via Boston)

Orange June 30th '51
My Dearly loved Brother,
Althouhg you
did not ask me to write you again
yet I shall not take the hint quite
yet if you intended for me to - I ought
to have written you long ere this but
I have had so much to do that I have
delayed. Yesterday I got my writing materials
but it was so extremely warm that I
could not write.
I am at Orange am enjoying myself very
much. My school is very large it so
56 scholars they are from 9 to 15 years of
age - My room is very convenient and
my boarding place joins almost. My health
is better than it has been for a long
time - I have felt for the two last weeks
almost perfectly well though my limbs
trouble me by spells and am almost
afraid that they always will the first week

of my school I was afraid I should have to
give it up for I was as lame as ever but I got
a wash and some Iodine and they are much
better - I had a letter from Mother last week
she is quite well for her and seemed in very
good spirits - Mrs. Stone they thought was
dying a week ago last Wednesday but she
wrote she was more comfortable - Old Mr. Miller
is failing very fast. Annette Perkins attempted
to elope week ago yesterday with Mr. Neaton [?]
who has been west teaching he is about 40
years of age he was at home the last time
you was here I believe. Her folks had forbidden
his coming to visit her or her having anything
to do with him and had watched her but
they had it planed so that a man came
from Fitzwilliams to the meeting house and
she left the sabbath school and went her
sister followed her out but she had got started 
Mary went home and Old Mr Perkins swised[?]
all the village and they started for her
but she would not consent to come back till
she was married unless they would give their

consent for her to have him. Monday morn
Arial, Daniel & Joseph all went over to see
her but she would not come back with them
but would not be married till Tuesday and
if they would then consent for Mr. Newton to
visit her she would put it off for Tos[?] 6 months
and so they consented - Her father and Mother
were about crazy[?]
I went over to Petersham with Mr Willis the minister that
preaches here last week Saturday and spent
the sabbath - they are expecting you there to
teach in the Autumn. The people are
well as a general thing - Mary J Weed is failing
Lydia's health is quite poor. She sees no one
hardly - Tuesday morn we are having a delight-
ful shower - Yesterday and last night are
called the warmest that we have had for
a long time - David is at Roycheston[?] to work
and has been for a long time will come
back here I suppose in a week or two - 
He was down Sabbath I asked him if he 
wished to send any word he sends his love
to all he seems to think that that is about

as much as he gets from most of you
as it is school time I must leave.
Wednesday morn I would commence you
a new letter if I was sure I could finish
it yesterday I had to set my coppies for
about fifty and I teach needle work one
night in the week and then cut drapes
some I have cut but 2 for a week here
one to do to night - I board with a 
widow lady - Mr. Willis the minister and
his daughter who teaches the Infant school
and Doc & Green board here. I enjoy their
society much and I think that I may
learn much by having them converse.
You said you thought you wrote as
much as you could about Erasmus
you did not say one word sure you had
been there - Give my love to all the
people and tell Sarah and Jesse to 
write me soon - I wish I could see you
all - my school will be done about the 
time you will be at home I am antic-
ipating much pleasure in being with
you and sister once more - Please write soon
for I love to here from you all so well 
Affectionately Lydia

August 27th/53
Dear N, 
I am almost vexed this morning for your part of the 
mail has all been sent to Beverly. I have just written to the P.M. 
to send it back - Mr. Bishop says that Alfred Marshall [illegible] 
it & Alfred says he did not that Mr. Bishop did it but he 
told him to send it to Belpre but he understood to Beverly 
I shall get it Monday I expect I should have written you the 
first of the week but have been waiting to hear again from Mr. 
Towne I think we shall have him for teacher tho, perhaps
not - The French teacher from Clinton has written to come 
also - If Mr. Towne don't come I expect I shall have to com-
mence with what assistance I can get till they find some-
one - Mr. Towne is the only one that has written to come -  Mr.
[Barren?] is coming & is to have the house that Mr. Scot used to have in

Edwin is going to Raymonds the middle of Sept - 
Myron has been having a very severe time I would
send you Sarah's letter but I sent it to Josie & she will 
write you about him - Jesse thinks of going east
Mrs. Gates is sick also Mr Clark but is better - 
The term will not commence till the 12th instead of 
the 5th - I will write you a long letter and tell you 
everything as soon as we hear again from Mr. Towne 
Write soon & tell me about  Erasmus & folks How is
your health & do you like your employment  
With much love Lydia

Marietta Sept 11th / 53
My dear good Brother;
I've half a mind to scold my
self for delaying so long to answer your kind letter
but last sabbath I took my portfolio with the
intention of writing you & wrote to David Jesse
& Sarah and then thought it best to wait till
Monday night as the trustees were then to have a meeting
They met Monday & agreed to pay me $100 & board
for the next term I've no fault to find with the
pay but sometimes feel almost sorry that I've
thought of staying but glad at others. I proposed
leaving at the time Mr. Towne decided not to
come but the Trustees would not consent they
said if I left the school must stop for they
could put it in charge of no one else till they
found a Principal & would get whoever they
could that I'd propose to assist me. I mentioned several but
they thought Jose & Mr. Hornbrook preferable
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
the money till this term is through I'll keep it if so I can get some of
the trustees you left but 8 books I thought that there was more. How do 
you do & like your employment? Please write soon. I will send you some 
papers tomorrow & each week after they have been send[?] at the Institute 
I will write you some
thing how the mister[?]
stands between the Inti-
tute & R. Road company
next time - our No
was 32 will write soon
In Love
Lillie
[Lydia]

and they made arrangements accordingly but
Mr. Hornbrook told them that the thought
he & I could do all there was to do. I dread teaching
with him for we are so unlike & he is different
from any person I've ever been acquainted with
I hardly know yet how to take him shall like
him I presume when I know him better - He thinks
there is no need of ones caring[?] for anything that is
said is done that it is all foolishness & every one
may overcome it if they choose. Many of the people
& scholars feel as if he would hardly answer
as he has been a scholar but I tell them that
I think there will be no trouble. The trustees
said that they wished nothing changed in school
and that I'd see that everything was carried on 
as before I told them that I should have nothing
to do with the school if there was any change
Mr. H. proposed having all the chapel exercises[?]
dispensed with but I told him that I could
consent to have nothing but prayer omited and
not that if he could be disposed to lead in 
it. I hope Mr. Barron will be there a part of
the time - He has said nothing in regard to the
lessons only spoke of several that he was to have

and during his remarks one day we were speaking
of the analysis class & he spoke of having it & I se-
[?] asked that if there was but one I'd like it as
it would be composed mostly of my old grammar
class but he said he should much prefer it him-
self so I said nothing more & presume that he ex-
pects me to take the remainder after he has picked
but perhaps not only that I do not understand him he
is so abrupt in his remarks. He says that he thinks
there ought to be one of us to appeal to in every case
but I told him & the trustees that I should not consent
to go to him to ask what to tell any scholars or if any
asked me a question to send him to him and I would 
not consent to his doing it to me but that we both
ought to have the privilege of saying yes as no & that
both should carry out what the other said & the
trustees said it should be so & that they only get him
to assist - They hope to get a Principal ere long -
Several new students have come and felt quite dis-
appointed and to find you but are going to remain
Hannah Wells & sister & Lille Gex are coming back
I dread that - enough about the school till I know
something - Jose I suppose wrote you in regard to
Myron did she not? Jesse is with Sarah now

and has the fever & ague badly - has she not a hard 
time? Mr. Hornbrook has just been here & I feel quite dif-
ferently in regard to the school he was not quite so adrift
Mr. Clark is getting better so that he is up & dressed. He
said the days I staid with him that he hoped to live
to see you for he thought you the kindest man he
ever knew there are many that inquire for you - 
Mr. Grippen from Ind. is here says he has a big
great desire to see you I like him much & all of 
the new students that I've see. Mr. Pierce son from Ind.
Mr. H. says he thinks superior to any scholar that has
been to the Institute wishes much you was here Mr.
Broughton has buried a son - Mr. Bacon of Philadel-
phia is to preach here the 4th Sunday of this month
David is at Fitchburg & thinks hard that you have not
written him since you was married - Edwin is going
to Galesburg  am almost sorry but perhaps it may be 
well for him - I do wish that you could have Jesse
with you I feel so badly about his being where
he is. I want you to write me all about Erasmus
and his children you did not mention them
Mrs. Deval told me to send you a kiss from
her & not to forget it Monday morning I staid with
Josie last night our school opens this morning. will tell
you the No. when I come back. Mr. and Mrs. Holden send respects
I am disposing of some of those Physiologies & if you do not need

Tuesday Evening Nov. 14th
[1854]
Dear Brother, 
Your letter reached
me Saturday evening & I had one
prepared to send you but thought
I would add some more.
You spoke of the different views
we entertain upon religion. I 
think our views coincide in
nearly ever particular & I don't think
we ever differed as much as you have
supposed. You Sarah & perhaps I
may add all my family friends
have known very little of me or my
feelings in past days only those
I could not conceal. Had it been
otherwise all perhaps might have
judged of me differently in some respects
I am very sensitive & have always been

from a child but naturally lively
& happy. I am quick & also possess
too much of the love of appretiation (sic)
you well know Fathers oppinion (sic) of me
compared with his oppinion (sic) of Sarah
& I used often to feel this Mother & all
entertained nearly the same as it used 
to be the way to correct me by compar-
ing me with her which I could not
bear had another course been taking
I should have been quite different -
Many of my friends have remarked the
difference in me when with my own
family & when away - Not have I have 
loved them all devotedly & felt this
they loved me but I never could get
over the impressions of early life & 
feel the same confidence to do or to
talk before or with you as others
I know I am and always was very un-
like Sarah. I possessed a much 
wilder nature & was subjected to

to very different influences while
young. Had I been governed by the same
mother in all respects as she I feel that
I should have caused Mother much
less trouble but so scolding & faultfind-
ing served only to add fuel to the
fire in my case - Sarah never had
any of the trials of early life to contend
with to which I have been subjected -
My task I could bare performed with
much better heart could I have
felt that I was regarded with the 
same favor as I felt that she 
was - But this does not trouble me
for I seldom allow myself to dwell upon
the past but am resolved to
make the best of the future & im-
prove myself as best I can -
You ask if I have ever read any
of Swedeborg's writings I have some
& am acquainted with some of that
faith - I can't say that I approve
of your idea of Libbie coming to La
Porte for it would leave her much
alone -

you speak of her being one of the
best little girls you ever saw - 
She is a good girl & I never
saw a girl of her age do better than
she did when with Josie but at home
I never saw a crasser & Carper [?] girl
than she was during the four weeks
I spent there Areli [?] was far better
at home & had a severe trial with
Libbie. I think Areli one of the best
girls I ever saw but Libbie is infe-
rior intellectually to her - Mr. & Mrs.
Hortryll are at St. Louis -
Have you ever read The life of
Hosen [?]  Ballon by his son? I am
reading it now - Do you think of
visiting St. Louis this winter?
With much love, Lillie

[to Peru IN)
St. Louis Sept 3 [1854?]
My dear Brother Nathan,
I will write you 
a short letter at this time for it is too
warm & I have too severe a cold to do 
more. It has been burning hot & very dry
here since last May. I haven't written
or done anything else I could help. I never
felt so miserably in my life as I have this
Summer no energy is patience & more
than half sick. Shall not try staying in
this climate next Summer if it is so
warm & it produces the same effect upon
me - We have been "up the river" and
spent two weeks at Hannibal two at Quin-
cy & more than one at Carthage with 
Rebecca & Sophia. It is warmer now
than when we left & then we felt as if we could
not stand it. I have been in school one 
[written on left-hand side of the page]
do care but will take the lowest. Do wish he could be with
David & work at his trade he needs to he with some one that cares
for him for
the present
with love
Lillie

week & have had a melting time of it.
I don't like my place & shall not stay lon-
ger than I can find another one but
think I better stay here till I can suit
myself better elsewhere. I have one of the
assistants places in one of the Day [?] Grammar
Schools & am the only lady connected
with the school. Two male teachers besides
I have but $350,00 a year & now have to 
pay $3,00 per week for board & shall
have to pay more if other things rise.
I have a correspondence with people from
Wapello Iowa & if they will pay me $500,
shall go or if they will give me enough to
pay me for changing. I think now I should
have done better to have gone to Peru
but thought from what they wrote me
that there would not be any trouble in
finding me a place. If I remain here
a while I can have a Principalship
at 500,00 but feel as if I ought now
to be earning something

Cousin Sophia is also out of a place
Raymond wrote me to come to Galesburg
but Sister & I felt I had better not go
That it would be better for a stranger
to be there. I might do well I presume
to go back to Marietta & establish a school
upon my own hook but don't like to.
Hope I shall get a favorable answer from
Wapello yet. Have you decided yet wheth-
er your work will stay as not if so
shall you not come here. We want
to see you very much. Myron seems
about as he was when I came here. Is to have
his leg opperated upon soon. Sarah
is well & has a fine lively healthy baby
which is a great feet. We will tell you
all of Rebecca when we see you if you
come. They are now building them a nice
large comfortable house. Why does not
David write me? he used to write me
often but of late have not heard from

him in a long time - Want to see him
much Will he go back if he goes to work
at his trade? Will you send me that
paper pattern of Josephine's ottoman? 
I sent it her just before I left Marietta
I would not ask for it but no one else
can be benifited by it & it is better than
mine for M. Holden drew mine from
it. We felt very much disappointed at
not seeing you Sarah staid at home
on purpose. I don't feel as if I was im-
proving in the least but rather going
backwards. I wish I could get a good
place where I should have to study &
get pay enough to pay my expenses so that
out of school I could feel as if my time
could be devoted to improvement. I am
tired of draging out life in this way - Doing
myself & no one else any good. Hope when cold
weather comes I shall feel differently if not I
shall flee far I think it a sin to do & feel
as I now do - Please write soon & excuse
more for now & hope when I write again it
may be cooler. Love to David.
