St. Louis Sept. 24th 1854
Dear Brother Nathan
I received your letter
yesterday & was glad to learn that you
were succeeding so well & that your health
was so good as usual. Myron had his
limb attended to yesterday. The oper-
ation was very severe. There were 14
Docs here some came to see the 
opperation performed. The old bone
is now all out & the new bone &
flesh seem in a health condition
so we hope it will soon be well.
I have now a very good opportun-
ity to open a sell it School at Quincy
& have engaged to do so the 2nd of
Oct but am teaching here now. If I
had remained here I could have had
a Principalship at $500 or 600,00
in a few weeks but it would have
been hard. I should have had the

[illegible] change
of from 150 to 200. At Quincy I
hope in a short time to do as well
& I shall not have as much care
& my school will be of an entire
ly different character. I dislike to 
leave here for I have just got ac-
quainted & like. I want to ask a favor
of you & that is that you should
find out if anyone at La Porte
knows a gentleman who was there 
last Autumn by the name of Mr.
A. Floyd Frazer. I have received
three communications from him
& some of his Poetry which was 
published in the "La Porte Republi-
can Times" by Floyd. I have heard
nothing of him, till a letter last
night came & he is at Cedar
Rapids I own since last winter
the early part. If you can conve-
niently find out anything of him

I would like for you to do so imme-
diately & write me at Quincy.
Emily Anders of Hoisnas [?] one of the
Institute girls is dead - All are
well but Myron. Clara sits alone
& creeps is very playful & happy -
All send love - Write soon
With love
Lydia
I shall write David to-night

Quincy, Ill Oct 29th / 54
Dear Brother N-
I intended to have written you last
Sabbath but Mrs. Fox with whom I board was taken
sick with the Typhoid fever & my time was spent
with her & all my leisure time since. I am taking
care of her to day but will spend my leisure time with you.
Fine in regard to Myron's limb - it was not taken
off only the old bone taken out. The opperation was
severe than amputation but his limb is now
gaining very fast. The new bone & the sore scarred
in a healthy condition much more so than the Doct
anticipated. He thinks Myron will have a good leg
again perhaps in a year & perhaps it may take
longer. If you were to have seen it you wouldn't
have thought from the looks it ever could have
been well again. He is now doing well in everything.
[written on the left-hand side of the letter]
I had no object in asking of Mr. Frazer only to know if there had been a
man where by that name or if he had been written under an assumed name
I know nothing of him either from his writings or else ways. He wrote me first what
the commencement of the term after you left Marietta & before Josie left (as I showed the
letter to her) & addresses it to Miss L. Y. Kendall so I replied to it & told him of
her marriage &c. He wrote me once after that & sent me three or four papers
& till this September I've heard nothing
from him. He found out
some way that I was visiting
at Quincy & at Mr. Nortzell's [?]
& as I met with a gentleman
on board the boat with whom
I had some acquaintance I thought
perhaps it might be him. But from
what you wrote it could not be
I presume I shall never hear from
again as he had left Cedar
Rapids before my letter could
reach there. He said if I would per-
mit him he would explain how he
first came to write me &c. 
Is there any direct road between
here and La Fayette? I would like to
visit Erasmus family much also
Uncle Atkins folks - Do you ever
hear from Edwin? Please write soon
and take good care of yourself -
With much love
Lillie

He is now all about over the City but when I left
he could not move his foot from a pillow -
He is thinking of attending "medical lectures" this
winter. He is anxious to become a Physician & Myron
and Docts Pope & Perry [Pesz?] say that it is best for him
to be directed in that way. They are both much inter-
ested in him. Sarah is or [?] has been very sick with
the Belious Dysentery.  Mr. W wrote of her the 23rd For
ten or eleven days she has suffered much & been
obliged to lie in bed very still. She is slowly im-
proving. This morning she feels quite easy. For more
than a week she did not take a pastiele [?] of nur-
ishment - Her girl was sick and under the Doct's
care for two or three weeks before she was sick 
and was still sick when Mr. Weaver wrote so he
with what assistance Myron could render did the
work took care of Sarah & Clara &c.
He says Clara is a good girl very happy & well
is almost weaned & hardly asks for her Mother.
She is one of the best & most playful little things
I ever saw. I miss her so much I feel as if
I could hardly wait to see her. You ask if Sarah
is happy. I think she is as much so as she can well

be. Clara is I think changing her and making her
more as she need to be. She felt quite unhappy at
first about her and felt as if she should never
feel different toward her from any other child but she
is thinking as much of her as she well could She is
such an affectionate playful little thin she can't help
it. If Myron becomes well & Jesse does right I think she
will be happy. She has a pleasant home & good husband
& I think likes him. She has had so many cares
ever since she has been married she has had no
time to enjoy housekeeping. They don't know what has be-
come of Jesse. I feel anxious about him if he could but
once get in a good place I should have no more fears
for him but he is unfortunate about getting work
of any kind only rail-roading as something of that kind
You ask if I am making progress in spiritual life
I know I am not as fast as I ought still I am chang-
ed from what I have been I live to talk & think
of those things much more than formerly. I think of
the future with pleasure now & I can see wisdom in
all the dispensations of Providence. I am entirely changed
from what I was two years since in nearly everything.
I learned many useful lessons at Marietta though

some were very hard. I should have been ill prepared
to have succeeded here had it not been for some of
my Marietta experience. I met with much opposition
when I first came here from the Presbyterian because
I came through the influence of a Universalist but I have
nothing now & I have said nothing from the commence-
ment. My school is increasing so that it No.s about 30
now & I think it will be as large as I desire & yield
me often this term at the rate of $700.00 a yr. & perhaps
more. My tuition bill will amount to $150.00 &
perhaps $175.00 this term but several came in late 
so if I have as good a No. next term I think they my
amount to $200.00. My room I rent for $50.00 a year
but it was out of order & I was obliged to spend about
$30.00 repairing it & making some arrangements we couldn't
well do without. I had to purchase desks chairs &c. I have
rented it to the Campbellites for Sabbaths for $35.00
a year & they find table & chairs & the store & keep it
clean for Monday. They will save me about $60.00 this
year. I shall more than pay my expenses this term
and next term they will not be as much by $73.00 I think
I am glad you are doing as well & hope your health will
continue as good. I want if I am able to go East next Sum-
mer & wish if possible for you to go with me. Sarah thinks
she must want another year. Sarah Sanderson is just gone
with consumption they think she can live but a few weeks. I wrote 
her but she was unable to answer & you may Pasmenter[?] to write for her
She wished to be remembered to you. Achsok [?] and Mr. Harby-
ell are doing well and seem happy. Where is David & why won't
he write? I have written him twice since he wrote me.

[QUINCY OCT 31 Ill]
Rev. N. Kendall
La Porte, Ind.

Quincy Ill. Nov. 9th & 10th / 54
My dear Brother;
I received your note of Oct. 24th the
morning after my letter to you was mailed. I am
obliged to you for your trouble in making inquiries
about Mr. Frazer but still I am inclined to think
they knew little of him there. Instead of his leaving
there for the purpose of studying Law he has been
through with that Profession 3 years & practiced some
& would send you his last letter were it not so
long & the postage so much to send there & back
it consists of three sheets. In it he says: "I read the
Medical Profession, quite young, and upon the sole-
citation of my father, abandoned it for the Legal.
I was admitted to the Supreme Court of the state of
New York at the Capitol in Albany in 1837 at the
age of twenty-three. I located in New York but my
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
pay my way. I hope some time to be able to feel that I am doing
something for the future - Sarah is just able to go across the floor
Clara has been very sick they did not think she could live but
week was better when I heard last. Her teeth were her trouble. 
Where is David? Be careful of your
self Write fris[?]
With love
Lillie
I received a prize of $3 for 
my needle work like Josie's
Ottoman at the fair this year
here. Today they sent me a 
heavy Napkin ring marked
A.C.A.S. to Miss L Y Kendall.
I got the same amount as I
paid for taking lessons.
A.C.A.S. stands for 
Adams Co Agricultural 
Society.

previous labors has been so severe that my health
was much impaired, and I was advised to leave
the City in consideration of my nervous debility. I
went into Western Pennsylvania and formed a
partnership in the profession (where the editorial
notice which I send you was written) but it was of
short duration. The condition of my health compelled
me to leave my practice. I tried the experiment
of journeying which I found exceedingly beneficial.
My health is now good & I shall resume my practice
- if I live - as early as next Spring if not before - Whether
I shall remain in the West or return to the East
I have not yet determined; but shall decide within
a short time." He also says he has felt the need of
society widely different from that with which he has
usually met since travelling in the West and therefore
has tried to make his thoughts & would if sunshine
to themselves which the clouds of external nature
cannot darken nor overshadow. He also speaks of
the distorted views in Theology which often more
the beauty of otherwise brilliant and attractive minds 
which he frequently meets & adds: "The mind which
in the present age dares boldly to rely upon its

intertwine convictions - subjects the causes of its belief to
the severe exactions of logic and disclaims the cruel
theory of vindictive punishment in the moral government
of the universe, may often expect the poor encouragement
of cold looks and unkind words. But this should not
kill not dishearten us. The run[?] is not less glorious,
this his ways fall wide & rain into ungrateful space, and
that only one beam in countless millions answers the
end for which it ventures into the abyss." 
May not his avoiding conventional society & his
differing from many in his religious views be
one reason for their judging as they did?
Perhaps he may lack energy of character but it seems
to me it must have taken considerable to have
accomplished what he has done at his age. I would
judge that he had more poetry & romance in
his nature than many but not more than 
you. He is like you I should judge in many
of his feelings & passions much more of a religious
nature than most men. I however may be
widely mistaken in my expression of him. I have
never met him & perhaps never may. I may be
unwise in corresponding with him but Mr. Weaver

[Lydia]
did not feel so I like what I know of him by letter
He is one of the finest writers I have ever met & his
ideas are correct so far as I yet know I thought I
would say nothing of him in this letter but as you desired
me to I have done so - I know that I have not used
this freedom in writing & talking to you as I have with
Edwin or David especially upon Religion &c but till
lately I have felt afraid or rather no confidence to talk
with you or Sarah. Since being with Sarah at Mari-
etta during the last six months I have less [illegible]
of this feeling. I feel much more freedom to both with
every one than formerly - Religion does not seem so
unsound a subject as formerly -
My school is prospering as well as I could expect but
I don't like teaching alone for there is much more labor
for one to perform in taking care of a school alone
than for a division even if you have more scholars
under your charge. I think however I shall remain
here through this school year & then if I feel no
better contented & ca find a place in an established 
school I shall avail myself of it. My tuition bills I 
think may amount to $160. this term. With the
same scholars another term they will amount to $200.
I commenced with only 8 scholars & I have over 30 now & still
are having new ones. My horse [house?] is poor. My expenses are
a [illegible] deal this term. I don't expect to make more than

[QUINCY NOV 16 Ill]
Rev. N. Kendall
La Porte Indiana

Quincy Ill. Jan 1st / 55
My Dear Brother N.
This letter I dated more
than a week & a half ago but was interupt-
ed by callers and it was laid. Cousin S.
Kendall is with me now & we have just
moved our boarding place &c so one lei-
sure has been occupied.
Was glad to hear of the Petersham friends
I had not heard of the death of Sarah Ann
but supposed it must be so from what 
Mary Parmenter had written a few weeks
before. You ask if I have heard that
"Raymond had an addition to his family?"
I have heard that he has another

daughter. He is traveling now & will be
till next September for the purpose of
obtaining Scholarship. Edwin is about
10 miles from Galesburg & doing a good
business as I hear from a Galesburg
gentleman who has been in the vicinity
obtaining Scholarships - Edwin has not
written me since he left Buffalo why
I know not. I have written him sever-
al times but to no purpose.
We are having delightful weather. Christmas
and New Years it was warm enough to
sit with our windows open. We have had 
no snow only a few squalls here yet
I should really like a good sleigh ride.
Mr. Hartzill is preaching here and doing 
well. She has been down to St. Louis and

while there was sick with a fever. All
were quite well there when she left but
Myron. He is so that he walks all over
the city without a cane. He expects to have
another piece of bone taken from his limb
though it may work out.
Thursday evening: I had hoped to finish this
last evening but Mr. Dillings (the Unitarian
minister & one you heard at Petersham
while we were boarding at Mrs. Brooks)
came to spend the evening with us. He
visits us often for her says we remind him 
of home. I like him much he is very intelli-
gent. His lecture here this winter before the 
"Library association" is considered the best of
any delivered. I have more intelligent friends
to value here than in any place I have

ever been in. We have a Reading Circle
that is very interesting & I think will be
improving. Mr. Hortzell had a letter
yesterday from Jesse. Poor boy! he is doomed
to a hard fate. As he was going from st.
Louis to Edwardsville Ill. to work the
steps turned over & he broke his arm
so he has not been able to do anything
since. He is always meeting with some mis-
fortune. "Cousin Fie wants to know if cous-
in Nathan has forgotten cousin Fie & the
crowing chickens out to Uncle Franks."
I had a good long letter from Mrs. Welden 
today & yesterday & the day before some from
Hal & Ena Putnam & John Tesol I sup-
pose you ahve heard of all news from there
of Capt. Franks Borths [?] & Illegible leaving
the church &c - John Marshall is married

Doct Kunkle went to western I own last [illegible] and bought
uncultivated land without a house upon it and 
goes next month to take possession of it. Ms. K-
feels badly about it but says she shall try to
make the best of it. Mrs. Holden says that they
were disappointed at not seeing you this winter
you inquire for my health It was near better & per-
haps as good as now. My school is prospering as well
as I could expect - My scholars presented me with a
Writing desk filled with writing materials and a 
Silver Fruit knife for a Christmas present - All
seemed united - You ask if I have heard recently
from Mr Frazer? I have. He is now engaged in [illegible]
at Fox Lake Wisconsin. He has formed a partnership
with one of the oldest & most talented lawyers there who
has a very extensive legal business & is about establish-
ing a bank and wishes to devote most of his time to
this & Mr. Frazer is to have the charge of the office
mostly. His health is now very good. His Father is a
physician in Penn. I have no fears but he is a good
and honorable man possessing sufficient energy and 
stability of character to ensure him an honorable

position among other men - It seems that nothing
truthful was known of him at La Porte only that
he was there a few weeks - He is an only son &
his one sister she is to spend the Winter with him.
The reason of his traveling & leaving N.Y. & Penn was
his poor health - He did not expect to recover when
he first went South but now thinks him self
well. Are you as well as you were? Do you suffer
much more from your lungs? Take good care of
yourself. Please write soon. I want to hear from
David. With much love
Lille
Mr & Mr Harbyll & Sophia send love - Please pardon this
writing for my pen & ink are both poor & it is
late as we went to the lecture this evening -
I should love much to visit Uncle Atkins folks -
Do you hear anything from Erasmus?
Lillie.

[QUINCY JAN 12 Ill.]
Rev N. Kendall
La Porte, Indiana

Quincy, Ill. Feb 18th / 55
My dearly loved Brother,
Your good kind
brotherly letter reached me a week ago to
day after playing by the way for a long time
but was none the less gladly received.
To-day is one of the most charming of days every
thing looks bright and beautiful but still my
spirits will not sympathize with the spirit
of the day. I know not why but often I feel
more sad and lonely at the first approach
of Nature's smiles after a dull season than
at any other time. To-day is one of those days
that I would love to much to spend with
some of my own dear brothers or sister. I am
beginning to fear that I shall be disappointed
in my visit with sister during vacation
[Written along the left-hand side of the page]
Direct to Edwarsville, Ill. and Jesse will get it I presume
he was there only a short time since at work on a building
Yes I get a good deal acquainted with him and he is per-
fectly frank with Sarah and me
at all times. He makes
a confident of Mr. Hertz-
ell always now.
[Written along the right-hand side of the page]
Monday morning -
It is just two years this
morning since I reached
Marietta. How many changes
have occurred in my life
& that of my friends some pleasing
and not. I sometimes feel as if
I preferred not to live longer
I can see not little pleasure
in life & yet I think I am
[illegible] for the most of the
time than the greater part
of mankind. If we have no hope
of a future I feel that this life
would not be worth the
trouble of living for in this brought
many cares & troubles to our
family & I have many 
pleasures. I want to visit Erasmus
& don't know but I had better if I
don't go to N.E. next summer. how
much would it cost?

we have been anticipating a very happy
time and Sarah has been planning much
to make the time pass pleasantly but "the
river" is yet frozen very thickly yet if this weath-
er continues the boats may be running in a
week if I don't go to St. Louis I shall spend
my vacation at Carthage. I hope David will
be here to go to St. Louis with us if we can
go. My school closes the 2ond of March to open
again the 19th The prospects look fair - 
Raymond & Augusta have been here and spent nearly
two weeks got bound here by that great storm
I like Raymond much in most things
He says that Edwin is doing well and has
a very good practice. Augusta says she
thinks we do wrong to blame Edwin for
he is more than employed all the time and
is trying to situate himself so as to be free
with the world is very [illegible] in every respect
and she thinks will be himself again as soon
as he can feel that he is free. He is boarding
about 7 miles from Galesburg in the

county as he can do so much cheaper
than in town. Augusta says she has seen
him but two or three times. I am going to
write to him and see if I can't get an answer
I am sorry David is out of his place shall be
very glad to see him. Hop now he will not 
get here till my examination and then we
can spend vacation together. My examination
is the 1st & 2nd of March. Do you ever hear
from Frank Drown now? I wrote May more
than six months ago & she has not answered
My N.E. correspondents are all very dilatory excepting
Townshend folks - I don't like the idea of not
hearing from Phillipston or Petersham more
I had a letter from cousin Sarah Cheney
a few weeks since and she was feeling as if
you had been negligent but Augusta told me
that you had written before she left Phillipston
You ask if I won't think I have made rapid[?]
progress since I came West? no more than while
I was in the East. My tastes have not changed
in the least so far as I am aware. I have

changed much very much in having confidence
in myself and that is the most that I am aware
that I have changed. My views are the same
nearly in every respect as formerly only I have lost
many of my prejudices &c. I look back and
wonder that I was in every respect what I view
as sensitive as I was and being under the influence
and treatment to which I was subjected during
my early years. I wish you were here to go with
me to church this evening. We are going to
hear Mr. Billings the Unitarian minister
you heard him at Petersham once while
we were at Mrs. Bracks. I like him better
than any minister I have heard in the
West. He is very popular here as a lecturer
He spends one or two evenings each week
with us reading and talking. His subject
to-night is amusements. The other ministers
have been lecturing upon them for sometime
and the young men have desired him to do so
and be his exception. Mr. & Mrs. Hortzell &
Sophia send love. Please write as soon as
convenient. If possible as that I can get it before
I leave. With much love
Lillie
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
Love to David if with you. Mrs. Hortzell
wants to know where Mr. Bennet is for she wants to write him

[QUINCY FEB 10 Ill.]
Rev. N Kendall
La Porte, Indiana

St. Louis July 16th 1856
My Dear Brother:
You say you are glad
to hear from any of us even if you don't
write so I have concluded that I would
pen you a few lines though I can't
say that I enjoy writing with no thought
of receiving anything in return. I hardly
think many would believe me should
I tell them that I have 7 brothers all
of whom are capable of letter writing
& with whom I am on sisterly terms &
yet I have received but one letter
(& that from you) from all for more
than a year although I have written
all last and some of them two & three
times. David must have caught a new
streak for he used to write me often
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
sick but is much better. Tell David that if he will promise
to answer me I will open a new correspondence with him.
Hope we shall see you here this Summer at any rate
Wish you or some of you
would write & let us
hear from you soon &
often - Please tell me
immediately your
plans whether you
think you will go to
N.E. or not. All send
love to all -
With much love
Lillie.

What has come over the spirit of his dreams?
He denied me to write a young lady at
Plymouth & I did so but have heard
anything from her or him since.
Myron's letter reached here yesterday after
wandering long but was safe.
Do you have any warm weather with
you? We are having burning times every-
thing is parched and burned. Never
did we need rain more. Vegetables
are becoming so high poor people will
have to dispense with them. New potatoes
were 10 cents per quart last week.
I am free from school and have no
engagement to go in but shall go to teach-
ing again as soon as I can find a good
situation. I have sometimes thought that I
would not teach this coming year but
think I shall feel happier to do so. I
shall never be happy I fear not
to be earning. It has become a part of

my nature. Was there anything else I
could do by which I could earn as much
or more I would do it for a time rather
than teach for I am weary with teaching
though I think I can resume it again with
better relish than I left.
If I don't go to teaching and can get the
money and you decide to go N.E. & will
not object I think I will decide to go
with you. I am very anxious to visit N.E.
and Marietta but do not like to go alone
for should I I should have no opportunity
of seeing more than I did before. If I were
to teach & could go I would though the
schools here commence the 1st of Sept. If
you go & I do not I want to send for my
things as I think you can attend to there
boxing better than any one there. Wish
you would write me your intentions and
should you decide to go & I decide to ac-
company you I would omit getting frames

for my paintings as I am intending. I shall
go East next year if I don't this.
I had a letter from Mrs. Munrac day
before yesterday and she wrote that Jesse
was on the Rail-Road below there at
work what doing she did not know & had
not seen him. I do feel so badly about
him. can't bear to have him off by him-
self with such company. I do wish he might
get something else to do than rough work
with foreigners. I do believe if he could once
get a good situation he would do well
He has never had one yet & is discouraged
Sarah says tell Myron that they shall
expect that long letter of his which he
promised very soon. They will write him.
Tell him to [illegible] & remember & write
Mr. Wagle [?] as he promised for he has
been looking for it for some time. The rats
have caught all of Myrons chickens but
two. Dijon is well & full of life. Clara 
says sent Uncle Myron kisses - Tell I much of him
and his going to La Porte. She has been quite

[Sister Lydia]
St. Louis Aug 25th 1856
Dear Brother Nathan:
Your letter came duly here & I was glad of the change
in the time of commencing school sure
on one account but it may make
no difference in that. Mr. Billings of
Quincy is East & to leave for home
the 1st day of Sept & was coming via
St. Louis but I wrote him I should
be at La Porte instead but presume
he will not call as I wrote him last
night of the change & hope he will get
it if not some of you can explain to him
should he call. We have a good girl

& I could have left this week had it
been necessary but feel that I need it for
rest & saving. Mr. Weaver wants you
should he send [?] & bring the book
Myron took away with him sometime
since for they need it. Dr. Shaw's
work upon Cold Water treatment 
They are unwilling for one to take
my paintings & if it is not absolutely
necessary I think I had better leave
them as it injures them to carry about
I presume I shall have no scholars
in Oil Painting at present & for other
things I have & can get patterns as it
injures mine [illegible] to be used. If you will
bring one of your trunks it will ease
my getting a new one for the present
In regard to money I have $22.00
that is sent on interest & hope it
may be all I need till I get there
though I have several things I must

get yet so it may be safer for
you to take more than you need
if you can do so with no inconveni-
ence If not I can borrow here & return
though I should dislike to do it. If you
still think it best for me to take my
Paintings I will do so & if you can spare
the money till I am through the first
term I will get frames at Chicago
for my Oil the rest are all framed.
If you have time & it will cost you
no more I would like to go via
Quincy & Galesburg & stop over one 
train at G. The fare is one dollar
less that way to Chicago but it takes
some longer to go. We shall look for
you Saturday Shall we see you? I would
like to start soon enough to get
all settled Saturday before I commence
school. If anything should occur so that
you can not come please write me

soon enough for one to come via G.
If any letters come before you leave for me
please take them with you - All send
love. Clara has scratched a letter for
Myron but I will not send it but tell
him to write her a letter & send.
Sarah wants to know where the long 
letter he was to write them is?
With love
Lillie

St. Louis Apr. 18th 1858
Dear Sister Abby:
I did not in-
tend to delay so long in an-
swering your last kind musing
yet it has been so irrespon-
sible [?] for me to do other
ways It came just about
the time of our Festival &
Fair and the few days be-
tween that & my going to
Quincy were all occupied
with sewing for Sarah which
had to be done Since my
return (a week ago last
Thursday) we have been using 
every spare moment on
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
We all send Myron a letter in the same mail.

the yard & house cleaning -
We are alone for the present
as Miss Turner is with Mrs.
Maniford for a few weeks
We are going to paper the
double rooms & are going 
to do it ourselves & the
white washing too. We have
a new carpet for the
back parlor. They are going
to get new chairs for
the parlor. The ladies
gave them a new marble
top stand at the Fair
Ernest has just come up
stairs and sees me writing
comes & says "Up" to get
in my lap. He thinks he

must help. He Grows pretty
every day is beginning to talk.
Mr. Weaver is not well this
Spring & can endure very
little I fear he is going to
wear out soon as is already
worn out. He is not able
to do nearly as much to 
help us as if he were well
& Sarah & I are trying to
do all we can. I hope three
weeks more will see every
thing about the house in
order. Then I am going to
help her get hers & the chil-
drens clothes in order if she
goes East & then if you
want me for this Summer

I guess I shall come &
stay till after they come
back from the East. Now if
you had not wanted me you
should not have asked me.
Perhaps you may be obliged to
keep me too if N. can't get 
me a "Pass" back for my
purse is getting very low -
Yet it is much like the
[illegible] cruise of Oil never
quite out. The ladies gave me
a very handsome "Porte mirror" [?]
at the Fair but I can't get
anything to put in it. If I get
enough for my old one I
shall do well I have not bought
me a thing new only stuff for
a shirt & had my old travelling
bonnet fixed up for Spring - Shall
get nothing this Summer Aren't I
getting saving? Guess I shall need to be;

2nd
I have been queering some whether (
had better go to teaching again
this next year. I really don't
want to & feel that it is much
better for me not to do so only
pecuniary & am not sure that
I shall. The interest of what I
have will get me all the
clothes I shall need & I can
earn my board here or else
where. My health is very good
much better than ever before
yet my patience will need
strengthening. I have exhausted 
all I ever had in school
I have done very little sure what
I actually needed & [illegible] do
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
With much love Lillie
Much love to Brother

as much for myself when I am
not teaching as when I am - 
How do you enjoy housekeeping?
Are you doing alone? Should
like to make you a call - 
If Sarah goes East if you have
no objections I am going to
take Clara to your house
& Aunt Atkins What say
you? She talks almost every day
of going to see Uncle Nathan
& Aunt Abby. Little Sarah
thinks she had much rather
come & see you than go to
her Grandmothers yet Sarah
thinks she had better take
her. At first I thought of keep-
ing all three of the children

and keeping house but Sarah thinks
she will feel much easier to
take Ernest & then it would
be very inconvenient for me
here it is so far from every
one -
I am sorry that Mary
is no better I fear her lungs
may never be well. How
soon does Mrs. Lee break up
& go East? Eliza Meed told
me she was going also Mrs. K
Give them my love I tell them
I don't think it half fair for
them not to write me How
are Mr. Bennet & wife pros-
pering? Mrs. Munroe writes
that they are going to Kansas

in the fall. Has brother seen
the account of Hellen Regnier death
of Harmer? I will write Myron
with Sarah & Mr. W. soon.
Tell me truly had you rather
have me with you a while
this Summer or not? Tell me
just your preference & then I
will make my arrangements 
accordingly if Brother can get
me a Pass - When would you 
rather I would come if I come
Monday Evening - This has been fine
weather for washing to day - Every
thing seems growing rapidly - Don't you
want Sarah's receipt for soap? She
has Wisner's patent washing tak [?] now
so she has scarce any rubbing to do - 
We are going to have company tomorrow
& more on Thursday to spend the
week so it will put us back about
our work, Sarah & Clara send much 
love & kisses to you both & wish to see
you. All send love - Write soon

[SAINT LOUIS APR 22 1858 MO.]
Mrs. Abby J Kendall
La Porte Ind.

St Louis May 10th 1858
Dear Brother & Sister:
You
last missive reached me last
Wednesday noon while at the
dinner table & I intended
to answer it immediately but
have been too busy during
the day & too tired at night
Yesterday I went to church
all day as Sarah was not able
to go & so I did not come
home as usual till night
consequently did not write
yesterday & if I had it has
rained in torrents during
the day so you would have

been no wiser. If it is not
too bad [?] tomorrow Mr. W.
will go in town to market
& the P.O. in the morning.
If pleasant there are 14 or 16 -
coming out from town to
spend the day & evening -
We are through cleaning it
should have been today had
it been pleasant but as it is
we have not cleaned the
back stoop -
In regard to my coming to 
La Porte I will leave here
two weeks from tomorrow  (if
it does not storm too
bad & if it should the first
pleasant day) which will be my

25th. I can't possibly come before
I didn't feel ready to come then
but will do so if no preventing
Providence. We have not done
a stitch of sewing for Spring
for any of us yet. I guess we
shall have a sewing girl
next week. We hoped to this
but she was engaged. Miss
Turner has been with Mrs.
Manford for the last 6 or 7
weeks but will be back in
a week or two - I shall 
not consent to ask as much
for I don't feel capable unless
it is impossible (& that it
won't be) to find any one
that knows more than

I do. Mrs. Hortzell has been 
suffering ever since last
Dec. & is still likely to just 
from not having proper care 
from a nurse or rather from
not having dealt properly by -
I should have no fears after
the first week or 10 days but
should before. Sarah says she
that is with me to care for the children
would not dare to do it with
her experience - I don't feel
either that I am able to do
what sewing is necessary to be
done & all the work beside
but if you will get a girl
I will teach her to do the work
& see that it is all done
properly & the sewing is &
alas do what else there is to be
done after the first few days

If you can't get any one I will
of course do the best I can yet
I didn't feel willing to take the 
responsibility. To keep a girl
while can't no more than to
hire the washing & ironing
done & that would have to
be done certainly for a time.
I guess your "nice times doing
anything we please" you will
find all taken up with some
thing else on it will be
some thing quite new. I wish 
I might come next week
but don't see how it is pos-
sible for me to do so -
If I should find I could
[E25]

I will do so & write you
I wish you would find out
in regard to the time of
the cars reaching Chicago &
if I ever came through to
it [?] immediately & let me
know. I don't like to leave
here in the night for it is
so bad getting to the Depot
& I don't like getting in to 
Chicago alone at night
unless I could come right
through to L. & have you
meet me at the Depot. 
Please find out as soon 
as you can about this & let me
know. Sarah is having a dread-
ful time with her fall. It

is owing to taking cold in
a decayed eye tooth. You
would scarcely recognize 
her her face is so swollen &
purple. The rest are all well
except colds - I will make
no excuse for my writing
for it is excuse enough
for itself - I will not tell
you anything more till I
see you & then tire your
ears - Let me hear from you
as soon as convenient -
My congratulations to "Fan"
All send love & hope to
see you when they go East.
Sarah will write you by me
if not before - 
With love 
Lillie

I feel anxious Abby that you
should have a good physician
and experienced, prudent nurse
Abby. I will write you more soon
Sarah

[LOUIS 
1858
MO.]
Mr. N. Kendall
La Porte, Indiana

St. Louis, Dec 2nd / 58
My Dear Brother & Sister: -
I prom-
ised to write you immediately &
will just commence to night
although Mr. W. & Sarah both
say for us to go to bed & wait
till tomorrow. We have been
taking our first lesson on the
sewing machine this evening &
S. deferred writing. Mr. W. went
to town today but could hear
nothing of my box. I could
not tell him which express
it was sent by or how it was
marked for I forgot to inquire
for either but suppose either
the American or N.S. [?]
[E28]

Presume I will get it without
any trouble. I left La Porte
with Union Plank Road money
and of course can pass none
of it here but guess David
will exchange with me when
he comes.
Sunday Evening.
Mr Weaver
Sarah & Miss Turner have gone
to church & Mary & myself are
home with the children. I have
finished reading to them & they
are in bed & so I will pen
a few lines to you. I would
just like to look in & see
you all & have a play with
Eddy. How is he?
I had a very pleasant time in 
Chicago. Spent the night at
Cape Clement's as the street was
so bad D. could not get to
Aunts with a horse. When he

went to the Office in the morning
I went to Aunts & he took
me to Mr Burse after dinner & I remained
till after tea & spent the evening
at Aunts. St. Louis is nothing so
muddy as at La Porte or Chicago
although it is the cry that it was
never so muddy before. Today had
been a delightful day it seems
more like early Spring than 
like Winter. I had no idea of
the difference here & there.
The Fair comes off between
Christmas & N.Y.s. I enjoyed
church to day & thought of
you & wished you had a place
where you could go & enjoy. All
seem active & engaged.
Had I been here three weeks ago
I could have had the Principal
-ship of the McDonald school
& may yet before long.

Has Myron got him a situation yet?
Tell him to write us where to Direct
to Jesse & Robert also to Edwin -
All are well & were they here I
presume would have some word
for you. Mary says - Give my love
tell them "I am well and hope 
that they are enjoying the same
great blessing." Our love to
Myron [and] tell him to write and 
let us know how he is prospering.
Please write soon. 

                    With much love,
                     Lillie

St. Louis, Feb 21st/59

Dear Brother [and] Sister,
Here it is two months since I received
your kind letter & it is 
not answered. I delayed at
first because circumstances came
up that Mr. Weaver felt un-
decided about staying here &
I waited to have it decided
(He will remain) Since then 
I have been quite unwell. I
was threatened with Typhoid
fever but broke it so I am
confined to my room only 5 or
6 days yet an unable to do 
much for a much longer time
it is more than three
weeks since I was first taken 
& and I am not quite well yet.
I am sorry that you are so
unwell.

The children are all quite
unwell with colds & we almost
fear it may prove something
more. Ernest is quite sick &
it hardly seems like a cold &
yet he has a severe cold & we
fear lest it may be [long] fever
as several children have died
here with this. There has been
much sickness & many deaths
here among children & par-
ticularly among our friends.
I suppose Mary told you
that my box of Paintings all
came safely & I am much
obliged to you for your care
& trouble of them.
Mr. Weaver & Sarah had a 
letter from Jesse a short
time since & he thinks
Kansas is played out & the
bubble burst. Says he has not
heard from Robert since

they parted before he reached
his destination. Have any of
you heard from him?
Mr. Weaver's horse has been so
lame he has not used him for
2 months. Last week he tried
to get him to town to be
taken care of but he got but
a little ways & he became so
bad he could hardly get him
back. He can hardly touch
his foot to the floor. As soon 
as it gets a little warmer he
is going to turn him out &
let him take his chance. I hope
he is not going to be good
for nothing for Mr. Weaver
can hardly afford to lose him.
No he has never heard any
thing from Bijon[?]. He has
stolen no doubt for a great
many other horses here boss[?]
Charly is a large strong family

horse & kind & it seems to
hard for him to be of no use
for we need him so much - 
Give my love to Fas & her son
& tell them I should much
like to see them. I dreamed of
her not long since. Ernest &
the children remember her.
The other night as Ernest was
sitting with his mother he said
I want to go to Uncle Nathans
again & see Faney Tippy & Eddy
he often speaks of all. The children
have Eddy in most of their plays.
I should very much like to see
him for he is now large
enough to be of a little more
consequence. I presume he has
forgotten me long ago but I
guess I could make his acquain-
tance again - Have you heard
anything from Erasmus' folks?
It is a shame I have not

written them & will try & do
so soon. I received a letter
from Libbie Stedman a short
time since but presume
you have heard from her
too so I will not say more
I should os muhc like to
visit her.
We like the sewing machine
very much although we have
been discouraged. I have
got so I understand it
very well & can do work
that looks very well. It re-
quired a good deal of patience
& practice to understand &
run it well. I am going to 
make Mr. Weaver some shirts
on it now Sarah got the
cloth yesterday. I think I
can make one well in a 
day but she thinks not
we shall see.

Lydia [Sarah] to Nathan
and others not. The society are
unwilling for us to stay out
here - How are your lungs
Nathan? We feel anxious to
hear for David quite frightened
us. Mary & Myron are both
owing me letters. Has your
brother severe yet Abby?
Has Mrs. Munroe reached
La Porte yet? We are looking
for her here soon She is to
come this month & will visit
here first. You must be sure
to call on her & invite her
to visit you. Has Mrs. Nayes
come back? Please write me
all the news. My love to David
Mary & Myron & to all friends
& kisses for Eddy for I guess
he will understand those best. 
Mr. W. & Sarah send their love to
you all - So do the children & kisses
for Eddy - They often wish he was
here. Please write as soon as con-
venient. With much love Lydia

Friday evening I fixed & hemed
6 yds. of fine jaconet ruffling
& a fine handkerchief in less
than an hour & did it much
better than I could have done
it by hand I have not sewed
very much on it yet for my
work has been a good deal
of it that that I wanted done
well & I feared to do it on
the machine but now I have
got so I can do most quite
as well. I will write you more
of my success next as all I do
now that can be done I shall
do on it. It cost Mr. Weaver
$56.00 He got it at half 
price. It is one of the best -
I expect to go to the Normal
school as soon & I do up some
sewing I have promised for
Sarah. I shall not teach till
fall I presume. Mr. Wallace's

family have moved here from
East Cambridge & live in
that large stone house below
us - We like them very much
there are four grown daughters
& a son - Three of the girls
are old teachers & are going
to the N. school & going into 
the city schools. The glass works
are bringing us several neigh
-bors - I have never known a 
family I liked more than
Mr. J Wallace's. They are
real energetic, high princi-
pled, well educated N.E.s
They have been used to good
society & are ready & willing
to go forward & make them
selves both useful & agreeable
We expect to go to the city to
live as soon as we can find
a home to rent. On some
accounts it will be pleasanter

[Lydia n.d. 1861?]
Dear Brother:
With Sister's letter I send a
corcheted sack for the baby which
I finished when I first came on but
expecting then to return to St. Louis
I deferred sending thinking it would
not need it before Aug. & I could
take it. I have another partly done
which I will finish & send if it
will prove acceptable & useful for
a change & this reaches there -
Perhaps it has enough already - I have
thought some this Summer that I
should spend the Winter with you
David, Erasmus & at Chicago I think
I wrote you so and told Myron
to tell D. so in reply to my not
spending my Summer there as he desir-
ed if it would be agreeable to all
but not hearing anything from any of
you I concluded to remain here.
I thought it would be pleasanter 
to visit the county here during

the Summer and it would not make
so much difference there - Our friends
are all as well as usual and inquired
kindly for you & yours - Provincetown
friends particularly - Delia White will not
last long - She is beautiful in spirit -
Lyman is in Mo. under Fremont -
How is Eddy? Want to see him very
much - Wonder if Myron went pro-
vided with needles, thread, buttons,
yarn &c &c together with sufficient
stockings & such necessary things - We
have worried some for [fear not]
but then thought Abby & Mary would
take sisterly interest enough to see
that he had all such going off for
such a purpose - All have been
thoughtful for the soldiers going from
here - Am sorry now as things have
turned that I did not come via La
Porte & make a short visit - If you
hear of any school in that vicinity speak
a word for me if you please - Love to
all - Kisses for Eddy & tell him Aunt Lillie 
wants to see him very much wonder if
he wants to see her -
With love
Lydia

Provincetown, Oct 19th 1862
Dear Bro N. & Sister Abby:
It is very long since I
wrote you last, how long I am unable to say 
& why I have neglected, I do not know,
only because I have been dilatory in all
my duties. I have the first two weeks
been answering all the unanswered
letters in my writing case, but I found
none from either of you but remembered
I was included with the others last
winter in your letters. I neglected to
write you with Sarah then, thinking
I would write you soon & wrote to
David then, but till now have not
set myself about writing you. Now I am
unable to direct to you but thought
I would write and send to Mr. Weaver
[written along the left-hand side]
and $9.10 for board & washing & ironing extra - which I don't think pays
I have always felt vexed that
I did not visit you as I came
on from the West but I had
no idea of staying and waited
tell I returned. Do you remem-
ber the folks here? They remember
you. Mrs. Hillard says she shall
the P.M. you & Mr.
Allen took tea with her how
much you all laughed -
Is this not the queerest 
place & yet the people
are real good - I should
like to see you all &
Eddie particularly - Ask
him if remembers Aunt
Lillie's singing to him?
I feel anxious to hear from
Jesse & Myron & suppose
I shall hear from Myron through Julia soon
shall be glad to hear from you both when convenient.

and let him send it on. I have
heard from you through the rest or I
should not have rested so quietly.
I suppose you are ably comfortable and
not as well as you were before your
sickness of last winter. A letter from
Mary two or three weeks since says:
David was over to see you & that you
were greatly troubled to get anyone to aid
you in your fall work. This is so all
through the farming country. I hope you
will not do to injure yourself; better
let your things waste than to get down
yourself. How do you both like your new
home? I have had two letters from
Erasmus recently; he says he was out
to see you but you were not at
home. He thought you had a very
nice place but feared you were
doing too much in improving it.
He seemed to feel badly that he
could not hear anything from you,
David or any of the boys only through
[written on the left-hand side of the page]
Do you know anything of Lizzie Stedman? Also Lyman White? Is Mary with you
still? if so give her my love. Kisses for the children. With much love
Lydia

Sarah & me. George & Lydira wrote with
him. Did you know that they named
the youngest little girl for sister Josie?
Lydia says she is pretty with curly hair
& bright black eyes. Marshall is a clerk
in a boat & shoe store, but E. wants him 
to go to school more, but feared to send
him from home on account of his wild-
ness, and was thinking of sending him
to South Bend to the Catholic school - I
have heard that school highly spoken of
but I advised E. to send him to Lombard.
If he should write to Pres. Weston he would
care for him I think. I would go to
Lombard myself this Winter and till there
was more call for teachers if there was
any chance for me to teach enough
to pay  my expenses. Augusta & husband
made Sarah a visit when I was there
during vacation. I received a letter from
Edwin written the 5th of Sept. in which 
he reports himself married. Of this
I am glad for I think he needed a
[written along the left-hand side of the page]
If you don't write so that I can get it in four weeks direct to
Lawrence instead of here -

wife and he is old enough to marry if
he is ever going to. Raymond's family
have moved to Young America & he
was expecting to go out in the 102 Ill.
Regt. in what capacity I don't know -
Of the La Porte friends you know as
much or more than I. Perhaps you
have not learned of the death of cousin
Ardelia Cheney. Aunt Frye wished Erasmus
to write you when she first died but
Emma said she had so much to do
that she neglected it. She has left three
little girls orphans. I am here teaching
and have four weeks more of this
term then they have a man for the
winter term. David's folks have sent
for me to come and spend the Winter
with them and I should go if it was not
for the expense and would as it is
if I thought I could get a situation
any where there or in the west in the
Spring or Fall. I presume I could have
an Assistant's place here at $14.00 per month
[Lydia 1862]

Orange Feb. 10th 1864
Dear Sister Abby,
I meant to have written
earlier in the week but if the mail
goes every day to Worwick it will 
make no difference. Monday eve -
ning I went out to Greenfield 
to hear E. H. Chapin and it
was a treat. Last night I had
to work from my school and
write a letter home so I trust
you will pardon my delay.
If it is comfortable travelling I
will come up next Saturday and
spend the time till Sunday.
Miss Wilber will come with me
and visit Miss Fanny Delvy

If convenient you may send
Miss Delvy word so she can be
at home. They live near I think
in the old tavern. I have but
two weeks longer to teach and
Sarah is anxious I should come
home as soon as possible.
Further particulars I will withhold
till I see you. Hope the baby
is well. Love to the children
& your Sister Mary.
If the weather should be unpleas-
ant next Saturday I will defer
till the following although I have
promised it to my cousin in
Athol.
With love,
Lydia
